THE THIRD SCRIPTURAL QUOTATION

gzugs ni dbu ba brdos pa 'dra/ / tshor ba chu yi chu bur bzhin/ / 'du shes smig sgyu lta bu ste/ / 'du byed rnams ni chu shing bzhin/ / rnam par shes pa sgyu ma ltar/ / nyi ma'i gnyen gyis bka' stsal to/ / zhes dang*/

Forms are like foam on water, Feelings are like water bubbles, Discriminations are like mirages, Formations are like banana trees, And consciousnesses are like illusions: Thus taught the Friend of the Sun.[158]

ji skad du/ rin phreng las/ theg pa che las skye med bstan/ / gzhan gyis zad pa stong pa nyid/ / zad dang mi skye don du ni/ / gcig pa de phyir bzod par gyis/ / zhes dang*/

In the Mahāyāna, the Buddha taught nonarising. [In the lower vehicles, he taught] emptiness as the exhaustion of all extraneous things.[160] Since exhaustion and nonarising are in actuality The same, accept [the Mahāyāna teachings]. (4.86)
lung lnga pa ni/
THE FIFTH SCRIPTURAL QUOTATION[161]

bcom ldan dngos dang dngos med pa/ / mkhyen pas kA t+ya yA na yi/ / gdams ngag las ni yod pa dang*/ / med pa gnyis ka'ang dgag par mdzad/ / ces phung po lnga sgyu ma la sogs pa lnga dang 'dra bar rang bzhin med par bstan pa dang*/ khyad par nyan thos rnams la nyon sgrib spong ba'i slad du 'du byed thams cad rang bzhin med par nyan thos kyi mdor yang bstan pa yin no/ /

The Transcendent Conqueror, through his knowledge Of things and nonthings, In the Instructions to Kātyāyana sūtra, Refuted both existence and nonexistence. (15.7) The above three quotations demonstrate that the five aggregates are without an inherent nature through comparing them to five things such as illusions. In particular, in the sūtras of the hearer and solitary realizer vehicles, the Buddha taught that all formations are devoid of an inherent nature in order for the hearers and solitary realizers to relinquish the afflictive obscurations.
lung drug pa ni/
THE SIXTH SCRIPTURAL QUOTATION

rin po che'i phreng ba las/ nyan thos theg pa de las ni/ / byang chub sems dpa'i smon lam dang*/ / spyod pa yongs bsngo ma bshad des/ / byang chub sems dpar ga la 'gyur/ / byang chub spyod la gnas pa'i don/ / mdo sde las ni bka' ma stsal/ / theg pa che las bka' stsal la/ / de phyir mkhas pa rnams kyis bzung*/ / zhes gang zhig gal te nyan thos kyi theg pa las kyang chos la bdag med pa bstan na de'i tshe theg pa chen po bstan pa don med par 'gyur ro snyam du sems dpa' de'i lugs de'ang 'di ltar rigs pa dang lung dang 'gal bar rtogs so/ / theg pa chen po bstan pas ni chos la bdag med pa tsam 'ba' zhig ston par byed pa ma yin gyi/ 'o na ci zhe na/ byang chub sems pa rnams kyi sa dang pha rol tu phyin pa dang smon lam dang snying rje chen po la sogs pa dang yongs su bsngo ba dang tshogs gnyis dang bsam gyi mi khyab pa'i chos nyid kyang yin no zhes bstan to/ /

From the Precious Garland: In the vehicle of the hearers, There are no teachings on the aspirations Of bodhisattvas, nor on the bodhisattvas’ conduct or thorough dedications. Therefore, how could one become a bodhisattva through that vehicle? (4.90) The topics on abiding in the bodhisattvas’ conduct Were not taught in the collection of sūtras [of the lower vehicles], But were taught in the Mahāyāna. Therefore, learned ones accept [the Mahāyāna]. (4.93) This quotation demonstrates that it contradicts scripture and reasoning for a philosophical system to hold that the Mahāyāna is meaningless because phenomenal selflessness is taught in the vehicle of hearers. For, the Mahāyāna does not merely teach phenomenal selflessness. What does it teach? It teaches the bodhisattvas’ grounds, perfections, aspirations, compassion, and so on, along with their complete dedications, their two accumulations, and the inconceivable true nature of reality.
lung bdun pa ni/
THE SEVENTH SCRIPTURAL QUOTATION[162]

'jig rten 'das bstod las/ mtshan ma med pa ma rtogs par/ / khyod kyis thar pa med par gsungs/ / de phyir khyod kyis theg chen las/ / de ni tshang bar bstan pa lags/ / zhes nyan thos kyi theg pa ni nyon sgrib tsam spangs pa'i phyir chos kyi bdag med mdor bsdus pa tsam zhig bstan la/ theg pa chen po ni shes sgrib spangs pa'i phyir/ chos la bdag med pa rgyas par gsungs pa yin no zhes bstan to/ / des na chos kyi bdag med rgyas bsdus kyi don chos nyid bdag med pa'i rang bzhin de khyad gzhi kun rdzob pa'i chos can ma lus pa dang rten brten par 'brel bar mngon du mi byed pa dang byed pa las der 'jog pa sogs rgyas par TI kar 'byung ba yin no/ /

You taught that there is no liberation Without realizing freedom from characteristics (tsenma mepa/mtshan ma med pa). Therefore, in the Mahāyāna, You taught freedom from characteristics in a comprehensive way. This quotation demonstrates that the Buddha taught phenomenal selflessness more extensively in the Mahāyāna. In the vehicle of hearers, only the afflictive obscurations are relinquished, and thus phenomenal selflessness was merely presented briefly. In the Mahāyāna, the cognitive obscurations are also relinquished. The differences between the vehicles of the hearers and the Mahāyāna are explained in detail in this section of the Ṭīkā, which posits differences such as the brevity or extensiveness with which phenomenal selflessness is taught. Whether one is “extensive” or “brief” depends on whether or not one realizes the relationship that apparent phenomena have with phenomenal selflessness in every single instance of relative truth.[163]

de tshe de la rdzogs sangs byang chub rgyu/ / dang po sbyin pa nyid ni lhag par 'gyur/ /
At that time, the first cause of perfect buddhahood, Generosity, becomes preeminent. (1.9ab)

zhes pas bstan/ sa dang po thob pa de'i tshe sems dpa' de la rdzogs sangs byang chub kyi rgyu phar phyin bcu las dang po sbyin pa'i phar phyin nyid ni ches lhag par 'gyur te/ phar phyin de rnam mkhyen gyi rgyu dang po yin pa'i phyir/ tshul khrims sogs gzhan yang med pa ni min no/ /

At the time of attaining the first ground, from among the ten perfections, the causes of the enlightenment of perfect buddhahood, generosity (dāna, jinpa/sbyin pa), the first, becomes vastly preeminent in those bodhisattvas, because the perfection of generosity is the first cause of omniscience. However, it is not the case that these bodhisattvas are devoid of the other perfections, such as discipline.

rang sha ster la'ang gus par byas pa yis/ / snang du mi rung dpog pa'i rgyur yang 'gyur/ /
They give even their flesh respectfully, Which provides a cause for inferring the unseen. (1.9cd)

zhes pas bstan/ de'i tshe sems dpas des dngos po phal pa la lta ci smos/ slong mo par rang sha bcad nas ster ba la'ang gus par byas pa yis las de ni snang du mi rung ba'i sa dang po'i ngo bo yon tan dang bcas pa dpog pa'i rgyur yang 'gyur te/ bdag gzhan rang bzhin med par mngon sum rtogs pa'i snying rje chen po rgyud la ma skyes na rang sha ster ba la gus par mi byed pa'i phyir/

At that time, let alone giving ordinary things; the bodhisattvas are respectful even when cutting off their own flesh and giving it to beggars. This type of action becomes a cause for inferring the unseen essence and qualities of the first ground.[164] For if great compassion, which directly realizes that oneself and others are devoid of an inherent nature, was absent in one’s mindstream, one would not be respectful about giving away one’s own flesh.

2.2.2.1.1.1.2.2.2.1. THE REASON WHY THE VICTORIOUS ONE TAUGHT GENEROSITY FIRST
skye bo 'di kun bde ba mngon 'dod cing*/ / mi rnams bde ba'ang longs spyod med min la/ / longs spyod kyang ni sbyin las 'byung mkhyen nas/ / thub pas dang por sbyin pa'i gtam mdzad do/ /

All beings strongly desire happiness, Yet for humans, there is no happiness without material enjoyments. Knowing that enjoyments, in turn, come about through generosity, The Sage spoke of generosity first. (1.10)

zhes pas bstan/ phyin ci log la mngon par zhen pa'i bsam gtan gsum pa man chad kyi so so skye bo 'di kun 'khor ba'i bde ba sdug bsngal gyi rang bzhin can de la mngon par 'dod cing mi rnams kyi tshor ba bde ba'ang rang rgyu zas gos la sogs pa'i longs spyod sdug bsngal gyi rgyu can yod na 'byung zhing med na 'byung ba min la/ longs spyod kyang ni sbyin pa las 'byung zhing sbyin pa ma btang na ni mi 'byung bar mkhyen nas thub pas tshul khrims sogs kyi gtam las dang por sbyin pa'i gtam mdzad do/ /

All ordinary beings—those who misperceive phenomena and dwell on a level below the third meditative concentration—strongly desire the happiness of saṃsāra, which is of the nature of suffering. Yet humans can only experience the feeling of happiness through the specific causes of that happiness: food, clothing, and so on, enjoyments which themselves involve causes of suffering. If humans have these enjoyments, happiness arises, and without them it does not. These enjoyments, in turn, come about through generosity. If one does not practice generosity they do not arise. Knowing this, the Sage spoke of generosity first, rather than speaking of discipline and so on.

2.2.2.1.1.1.2.2.2.2.1. HOW GENEROSITY SERVES AS A CAUSE FOR TEMPORARY HAPPINESS
snying rje dman zhing shin tu rtsub sems can/ / rang don lhur len nyid du 'gyur ba gang*/ / de dag gi yang 'dod pa'i longs spyod rnams/ / sdug bsngal nyer zhi'i rgyur gyur sbyin las 'byung*/ /

Even for those who are wanting in compassion, ill-tempered, And focused exclusively on their own concerns, The enjoyments they desire, Which thoroughly pacify their suffering, arise from generosity. (1.11)

zhes pas bstan/ gtong ba po gzhan don gyi ched kyi tshul dang mi mthun par gzhan sdug bsngal dang bral 'dod kyi snying rjes dman zhing gtong ba'i tshe na bsam sbyor shin tu rtsub pa'i sems can tshe 'dir sbyin pa btang na tshe rabs 'di phyir longs spyod thob bo zhes rang don lhur len nyid du gyur pa gang de rgyal sras sbyin 'bras mi gnyer ba sbyin pa'i dga' ston 'phel ba las zlog pa de dag gis kyang de ltar spyad pa las 'bras bu 'dod pa'i longs spyod rnams bkres sogs kyi sdug bsngal nyer zhir byed cing de'i rgyur gyur pa ni sbyin pa la yon tan du lta zhing mi sbyin pa la skyon du lta ba las byung ngo*/ /

Some people give in a way that runs against the aim of benefiting others. They are wanting in compassion, the wish to free others from suffering. They may also be ill-tempered in thought and deed, giving with only the thought, “If I give in this life, I will receive enjoyments in this and future lives,” focusing solely on their own concerns. They do not strive for the results of generosity sought by the heirs of the victorious ones. In not doing so, they turn their backs on a rich banquet of generosity. Nevertheless, their conduct will produce results: the material enjoyments they desire, which thoroughly pacify their sufferings, such as hunger. These results arise due to regarding generosity as a good quality and regarding not giving as a fault.
gnyis pa (mthar thug gi bde ba'i rgyu byed pa )ni/
2.2.2.1.1.1.2.2.2.2.2. HOW GENEROSITY SERVES AS A CAUSE FOR ULTIMATE HAPPINESS
'di yang sbyin pa'i skabs kyis nam zhig tshe/ / 'phags pa'i skye bo dang 'phrad myur du 'thob/ / de nas srid rgyun yang dag bcad byas te/ / de yi rgyu can zhi bar 'gro bar 'gyur/ /
Even they, through an occasion of giving, Will one day come to meet a noble being. Perfectly cutting through the continuum of existence, They will attain the result and proceed to peace. (1.12)

zhes pas bstan/ nyan rang gi rigs can snying rje chen po dang bral ba na rga'i sdug bsngal spong 'dod kyi sbyin pa gtong po 'di yang sbyin pa gtong ba'i skabs kyi dus nam zhig gi tshe gtong po de len po 'phags pa'i skye bo dang 'phrad de des yon bsngo bshad sogs 'khor ba las bzlog pa'i gdams pa bshad pas gtong po de myur du gdams pa thob pa'i rjes de nas 'khor ba la skyon du bltas la 'phags lam mngon du byas nas srid rgyun yang dag par bcad par byas te/ srid rgyun bcad pa'i lam de yi rgyu can gyi zhi ba nyan rang gi myang 'das der 'gro bar 'gyur zhing rgyu can myang 'das de thob pa'i rgyu yang nyan rang gi sbyin pa las byung ngo*/ /

Even those who have the disposition of hearers or solitary realizers, who do not have great compassion, through an occasion of giving motivated by desire to be free of the suffering of sickness and aging, will one day meet with a recipient of such generosity who is a noble being. This noble being will teach them the instructions on turning away from saṃsāra: they will teach them about good qualities, dedications, explaining the dharma, and so on. Not long after obtaining these instructions, the giver will begin to see the shortcomings of saṃsāra. They will actualize the path of the noble ones, perfectly cutting through the continuum of existence. Through this, they will proceed to peace, the nirvāṇa of the hearers and solitary realizers that is the result of this path. Therefore, this attainment of nirvāṇa also arises due to generosity.
gsum pa rgyal sras la myur du bde ba bskyed pa ni/
2.2.2.1.1.1.2.2.2.3. GENEROSITY QUICKLY PRODUCES HAPPINESS IN BODHISATTVAS
'gro la phan par dam bcas yid can rnams/ / sbyin pas ring por mi thogs dga' ba 'thob/ /
Before long, those committed to benefiting beings Will achieve joy through giving. (1.13ab)

ces pas bstan/ sbyin pas rnam smin la re ba rnams ni sbyin pa dang dus mnyam du sbyin 'bras la longs spyod pa min la/ byang chub sems pa 'gro ba la phan par dam bcas pa'i yid can rnams ni sbyin pas yun ring por mi thogs par dus mnyam kho nar de'i 'bras bu la longs spyod pas dga' ba thob par 'gyur ro/ /

Those who hope for the karmic ripening of their generosity will not enjoy the results of generosity simultaneously with the giving itself. However, bodhisattvas, who are committed to benefiting beings, before long will continually enjoy the results of their generosity, even while they are giving. Thus they will attain joy.
bzhi pa de dag gi don bsdu ba ni/
2.2.2.1.1.1.2.2.2.4. A SUMMARY OF THE ABOVE TOPICS
gang phyir brtse bdag brtse bdag ma yin pa/ / de phyir sbyin pa'i gtam nyid gtso bo yin/ /
Since it is for both those who are loving and not-so-loving in character, The teaching on generosity is foremost. (1.13cd)

zhes pas bstan/ gang phyir ji skad bshad pa'i tshul gyis brtse ba'i bdag nyid can gyi sems dpa' dang brtse ba'i bdag nyid can ma yin pa so skye dang nyan rang thams cad mngon mtho dang nges legs thob byed kyi rgyu sbyin pa yin pa de'i phyir na sbyin pa la bsngags pa'i gtam nyid 'dod bya'i gtso bo ste dang po yin no/ /

Generosity, as was explained above, is the cause for attaining the higher realms and definite goodness for those loving in character—the bodhisattvas—and for those not-so-loving in character—ordinary beings, hearers, and solitary realizers. Therefore, the teaching that praises generosity is foremost, and that is why it is given first.
lnga pa rgyal sras la bde ba bskyed tshul bye brag tu bshad pa la/
2.2.2.1.1.1.2.2.2.5. A SPECIAL EXPLANATION OF HOW GENEROSITY PRODUCES HAPPINESS IN BODHISATTVAS
dngos dang*/ sdug bsngal 'byung yang gzhan don 'phel ba'i rgyur 'gyur pa gnyis/
2.2.2.1.1.1.2.2.2.5.1. The actual explanation 2.2.2.1.1.1.2.2.2.5.2. Even if suffering arises, it is transformed into a cause for the further benefit of others
dang po ni/
2.2.2.1.1.1.2.2.2.5.1. THE ACTUAL EXPLANATION
ji ltar byin cig ces sgra thos bsams las/ / rgyal sras bde 'byung de ltar thub rnams la/ / zhi bar zhugs pas bde ba byed min na/ / thams cad btang bas lta zhig smos ci dgos/ /
If the joy the heirs of the victors feel Upon hearing “Please give to me” Cannot be matched by the joy of the sages entering peace, What need to mention their joy of giving everything? (1.14)

zhes pas bstan/ sems dpas slong po la gtong ba nyid kyis de dag yid tshim pa na sems dpa' nyid la dga' ba ci 'dra skye zhe na/ slong mo ba 'ga' sems dpa'i sgo drung du 'ongs nas ji ltar 'dod pa'i longs spyod byin cig ces slong ba'i sgra sems dpas thos pa na sems dpa' des bsam pa la slong ba po 'di bdag dang gzhan gang la slong ba yin snyam du rtog pa'i tshe rgyal sras bdag nyid la slong bar rtogs pa na rgyal sras de'i rgyud la bde ba 'byung ba de ltar thub pa nyan rang rnams la sdug bsngal kun zhi bar zhugs pa las thob pa'i bde ba des kyang 'gran par byed pa min na/ sems dpas phyi nang gi dngos po thams cad btang bas gzhan don gyis yid tshim pa'i bde ba ches cher 'byung ba lta zhig smos ci dgos so/ /

One may wonder, “What kind of joy do the bodhisattvas experience when they bring satisfaction to someone who has asked them for something?” If several beggars were to come to the door of a bodhisattva and cry out, “Please give this to me,” asking for whatever enjoyments they desired, when the bodhisattvas first hear this cry they will first wonder, “Are they asking me or someone else?” When they realize it is they who are being asked, these heirs of the victorious ones experience a joy that cannot be rivaled even by the joy of the hearer and solitary realizer arhats when those sages enter into the pacification of all suffering. Therefore, what need is there to speak of the even greater joy and satisfaction that the bodhisattvas experience when they benefit others by giving away all inner and outer things?
gnyis pa (sdug bsngal 'byung yang gzhan don 'phel ba'i rgyur 'gyur pa )ni/
2.2.2.1.1.1.2.2.2.5.2. EVEN IF SUFFERING ARISES, IT IS TRANSFORMED INTO A CAUSE FOR THE FURTHER BENEFIT OF OTHERS
lus bcad ster zhing bdag gi sdug bsngal gyis/ / gzhan dag rnams kyi dmyal ba la sogs pa'i/ / sdug bsngal rang rig nyid du mthong nas ni/ / de bcad bya phyir myur du brtson 'grus rtsom/ /

The suffering they experience when cutting off and giving their flesh Brings the sufferings of others in the hells and so forth Directly to the bodhisattvas’ minds. They then swiftly apply themselves to ending that suffering. (1.15)

zhes pas bstan/ de ltar sems dpas lus sogs gtong ba na lus sdug bsngal bar 'gyur ram zhe na/ byang sems chags med dang*/ chags bcas gnyis las/ dang po la ni/ lus bcad pa las sdug bsngal 'byung mi srid de/ chos thams cad rang bzhin med par rtogs pa'i phyir/ bems po bcad pa lta bu ste/ ji skad du nam mkha' mdzod kyi ting nge 'dzin las/ 'di lta ste/ dper na shing sA la chen po'i tshal zhig yod la der 'ga' zhig 'ongs nas sA la gcig bcad pa na der shing sA la lhag ma de rnams 'di snyam du 'di ni bcad pa'o/ / bdag ni ma bcad pa'o snyam du mi sems shing de la rjes su chags pa dang khong khro ba med do/ / byang chub sems dpa'i bzod pa de lta bu gang yin pa de ni bzod pa yongs su dag pa mchog nam mkha' dang mnyam pa yin no/ / zhes 'byung bas 'phags pa'i lus bcad pas sdug bsngal med do/ / byang sems chags bcas ni/ sems dpa' des lus bcad nas ster zhing de las byung ba'i bdag gi sdug bsngal gyi gdung bas gzir ba la rjes su dpags nas sems can gzhan dag rnams kyi dmyal ba la sogs pa'i ngan song gsum gyi sdug bsngal ches chen pos lus sdug bsngal ba ni bdag gi sha bcad pa 'di las stong 'gyur gyis lhag pa'i sdug bsngal sran du med pa de'ang rang gi sdug bsngal ji ltar rig pa nyid bzhin du mthong nas sems dpa' de ni rang lus bcad pa'i sdug bsngal la sdug bsngal tsam du 'ang mi lta bar dmyal sogs kyi sdug bsngal de rgyun bcad par bya ba'i phyir byang chen gyi ched du myur du brtson 'grus rtsom mo/ /

Do the bodhisattvas physically suffer when give their flesh and so forth away? There are two types of bodhisattvas: those without attachment and those with attachment. As to the first, it is impossible for them to experience suffering due to cutting off their own flesh, because they have realized that all phenomena are devoid of an inherent nature. Therefore their experience is just like the experience of someone cutting inanimate matter. In relation to this, the sūtra called the Concentration of the Space Treasury (Namka Dzö kyi Ting-nge Dzin/nam mkha’ mdzod kyi ting nge ‘dzin) says: It is like this: If there were a large forest of sala trees to which a few people came and cut down one tree, the remaining trees would not think, “They cut that tree down; they did not cut me down!” They would have no attachment or anger. The patience of the bodhisattvas is like that. It is completely pure, supreme, and equal to space. Therefore, noble beings have no suffering due to cutting off their flesh. As for bodhisattvas with attachment, the suffering they experience in their body from cutting off and giving away their flesh causes them to infer, from their own torment, the incredibly great physical sufferings of other sentient beings in the three lower realms—the hells and so forth. Through fully experiencing their own suffering, they see that the sufferings of the lower realms are a thousand times more intense and intolerable. The bodhisattvas, therefore, do not view the suffering that arises from cutting off their flesh as merely suffering alone. Rather, in order to put an end to the continuum of suffering of the hells and so forth, they swiftly apply themselves to attain great enlightenment.
gsum pa 'jig rten las 'das ma 'das kyi sbyin pa'i khyad par bstan pa la/
2.2.2.1.1.1.2.2.3. THE DIFFERENCE BETWEEN MUNDANE AND TRANSCENDENT GENEROSITY
'jig rten las 'das pa dang*/ ma 'das pa'i sbyin pa gnyis las/

dang po ni/
2.2.2.1.1.1.2.2.3.1. TRANSCENDENT GENEROSITY
sbyin pa sbyin bya len po gtong pos stong*/ / 'jig rten 'das pa'i pha rol phyin ces bya/ /
Generosity that is empty of gift, recipient, and giver Is known as a transcendent perfection. (1.16ab)

zhes pas bstan/ sbyin pa gang gis pha rol tu 'gro zhes pa'i pha rol ni 'khor ba'i pha mthar yod pa'i sgrib gnyis kyi spangs pa dang ldan pa'i sangs rgyas so/ / der son pa ni pha rol tu phyin pa'o/ / phar phyin du 'jog byed dngos ni sher phyin yin te/ des zin pa'i sbyin sogs byang chub tu bsngos pas pha rol tu 'gro ba nyid kyi phyir te/ sbyin sogs de dag la phar phyin gyi ming brnyed pa'i phyir/ des na sbyin pa sbyin bya len po gtong pos stong*/ 'jig rten 'das pa'i pha rol phyin ces bya bar bcom ldan 'das mar gsungs te/ de lta'i sbyin pa ni 'khor gsum du mi dmigs pa'i phyir/

The term “perfection” is derived from words that mean “gone to the other shore.”[165] What other shore does one travel to through generosity? The “other shore” is the state of buddhahood, in which the two obscurations are relinquished. This relinquishment is found on the “other shore” of saṃsāra. If a given virtue can help one to travel to this other shore, it is called a “perfection.” The actual quality that makes a virtue a perfection is the perfection of supreme knowledge, because one travels to the other shore through dedicating the generosity and so on that have been embraced by supreme knowledge to enlightenment. Supreme knowledge turns generosity and so on into “perfections.” Therefore, generosity that is empty of gift, recipient, and giver is taught to be a transcendent perfection in the Lady Transcendent Conqueror sūtras, because such generosity does not entail reification of the three spheres.
gnyis pa (ma 'das pa'i sbyin pa )ni/
2.2.2.1.1.1.2.2.3.2. MUNDANE GENEROSITY
gsum po dag la chags skyes gyur pas de/ / 'jig rten pa yi pha rol phyin ces bstan/ /
Generosity in which attachment to those three arises Is taught to be a mundane perfection. (1.16cd)

ces pas bstan/ sbyin pa gang la sbyin bya len po gtong po gsum po dag la chags pa skyes pa ste/ de ltar dmigs par gyur pas de 'jig rten pa'i pha rol phyin ces bstan te/ der dmigs pa ni kun rdzob kyi bden par lta ba nyid kyi phyir/

Generosity in which there arises attachment to the gift, giver, and recipient, or in other words, generosity in which those three are observed, is taught to be a mundane perfection because observing things in that way is the view of the relative truth.
gsum pa sa'i yon tan brjod pa'i sgo nas mjug bsdu ba ni/
2.2.2.1.1.1.3. A CONCLUDING SUMMARY DESCRIBING THE GROUND’S QUALITIES

de ltar rgyal ba'i sras kyi yid la rab gnas shing*/ / dam pa'i rten la 'od chags mdzes pa rnyed gyur pa'i/ / dga' ba 'di ni nor bu chu shel ji bzhin du/ / mun pa stug po thams cad rnam par bsal nas rgyal/ /
dbu ma la 'jug pa las sems bskyed pa dang po'o/ /

In this way they excellently abide in the mind of the heirs of the victorious ones. On the genuine support, they discover a beautiful light. This joy is just like the water crystal jewel: Completely dispelling the thick darkness, it is victorious. (1.17)
This completes the first bodhichitta generation from the Entrance to the Middle Way.

zhes pas bstan/ de ltar sa 'dir ye shes kyi yon tan la rjes su bstod pa ni/ bshad ma thag pa'i yon tan de dag thob pa'i rgyal ba'i sras kyi yid la rab tu gnas shing dam pa'i rten kun rdzob byang sems la don dam byang sems kyi 'od chags pas mdzes pa rnyed par gyur pa'i rab tu dga' ba'i sa 'di ni dper na nor bu chu shel las grub pa'i zla ba nya gang bas mun pa sel ba ji bzhin du rang gi ngo skal gyi sgrib pa'i mun pa stug po thams cad rnam par bsal nas rgyal bar 'gyur ro/ /

This verse praises the wisdom qualities of the first ground. The bodhisattvas on this ground excellently abide in the mind of the heirs of the victorious ones, who have attained all of the qualities described above. On the genuine support of relative bodhichitta, they discover the beautiful light of ultimate bodhichitta. This discovery is supremely joyful, and this ground, Supreme Joy, is like a full moon made from the water crystal jewel: just as the latter dispels darkness, this ground is victorious in completely dispelling the thick darkness of one’s own individual obscurations.
dbu ma la 'jug pa las rab dga' zhes pa'i sems bskyed pa dang po'i bshad pa'o// //
This completes the explanation of the first bodhichitta generation, Supreme Joy, from the Entrance to the Middle Way.

2.2.2.1.1.2.1.1. THE ACTUAL EXPLANATION
de tshul phun tshogs yon tan dag ldan phyir/ / rmi lam du yang 'chal khrims dri ma spangs/ /
Since they have the abundant qualities of discipline, They refrain from faulty discipline even in their dreams. (2.1ab)

zhes pas bstan/ sa zhes ye shes kyi ngo bo la ni rang ngo dbye mi nus pa rang bzhin gcig pa nyid yin yang tshul khrims kyi phar phyin sogs kyis phul du byung bas sa gnyis pa sogs kyi khyad par rab tu phye ba yin la/ der gnas kyi sems dpa' de rang sa'i tshul khrims phun sum tshogs pa'i yon tan dag dang ldan pa'i phyir/ rmi lam du yang 'chal khrims kyi dri ma spangs pa yin no/ / yang sgras ni sad pa'i tshe lta ci smos so/ / tshul khrims kyi nges tshig ni nyon mongs dang du mi len zhing*/ de 'bras sdig mi sog pas sems sim pa dang bde ba'i rgyu nyid kyis dam pas bsten bya yin pas so/ / ngo bo ni spang bya bdun spong ba'i yid kyi dge ba gsum dang bcas te dge ba'i las lam bcu'o/ /

As explained before, the term “ground” denotes the essence of wisdom, whose very nature is indivisible and singular. However, the differences of the grounds are clearly differentiated by the perfections that become supreme on them. The second ground, for instance, is presented due to the perfection of discipline (shīla, tsultrim/tsul khrims) becoming supreme. Bodhisattvas abiding on this ground have the abundant qualities of this ground’s discipline. Therefore, they refrain from faulty discipline even in their dreams. The word “even” in the second line indicates that one need not mention their conduct during waking life. The precise meaning (ngetsig/nges tshig) of discipline is as follows: it is called “discipline” because through it one does not engage in the mental afflictions, one does not accumulate the misdeeds that result from mental afflictions, and, due to that, one’s mind is satisfied and happy. Therefore, it is an object of reliance for genuine beings. The essence of discipline is to relinquish the seven factors to be relinquished, and to possess the mind of the three virtues.[166] This, in short, is the tenfold path of virtue.
gnyis pa (tshul khrims rnam par dag tshul rgyas par bshad pa )la/

2.2.2.1.1.2.1.2.1.1. THE PURITY DUE TO RELINQUISHING THE TEN NONVIRTUES
lus ngag yid kyi rgyu ba dag gyur pas/ / dam pa'i las lam bcu char gsog par byed/ /
Because the movements of their body, speech, and mind are pure, They accumulate the actions of the genuine ones’ tenfold path. (2.1cd)
ces pas bstan/ lus ngag yid kyi rgyu ba mi mthun pa'i dri ma dag par gyur pas sa gnyis pa'i sems dpa' 'di ni dam pa'i las lam bcu char yang rang gi ngang gis gsog par byed do/ /

Since the discordant stains of the movements of their body, speech, and mind have been purified, the bodhisattvas on this second ground naturally accumulate the actions of the tenfold path of the noble ones.[167]

2.2.2.1.1.2.1.2.1.2. HOW IT IS PURER THAN THE FIRST GROUND
dge ba'i lam 'di lta zhig bcu char yang*/ / de la klags te shin tu dag par 'gyur/ /
This virtuous path in its tenfold aspect, though practiced before, Here becomes supreme and extremely pure. (2.2ab)

zhes pas bstan/ ci las lam 'di dag sems dang po bskyed pa'i byang chub sems dpas bskyed dam zhe na/ des kyang bskyed mod kyi/ 'on kyang dge ba'i las kyi lam 'di lta zhig bcu char yang sems bskyed gnyis pa la gnas pa'i byang chub sems dpa' de la klags par te shin tu rnam par dag par 'gyur gyi/ de tsam du sems bskyed dang po la gnas pa'i sems dpa' la ni mi 'gyur te/ gtan du rgyun mi chad par goms par byed cing tshul khrims mi dmigs pa'i shes rab kyis kun tu spyod pa med pa'i phyir ro/ /

Do bodhisattvas who have generated the first level of bodhichitta also generate these ten virtuous paths? Indeed they do, but this virtuous path, in its tenfold aspect, becomes supreme and extremely pure in a bodhisattva who abides on the ground of the second level of bodhichitta. It is not this way for bodhisattvas who abide on the first bodhichitta level, because those bodhisattvas are devoid of the conduct that continually and without fail familiarizes them with the supreme knowledge that does not observe even discipline [as being truly existent].
gsum pa (dpe'i sgo nas dag tshul )ni/
2.2.2.1.1.2.1.2.1.3. THE ILLUSTRATION OF ITS PURITY BY WAY OF EXAMPLE
ston ka'i zla ltar rtag tu rnam dag de/ / zhi 'od chags par de dag gis rnam mdzes/ /
Like an autumn moon, they are always pure And beautified by peaceful light. (2.2cd)

zhes pas bstan/ de'ang dper na sprin dang bral ba'i ston ka'i zla ba ltar rtag tu 'chal tshul gyi rnam par dag pa'i sems dpa' de dbang po bsdams pas zhi zhing lham mer gsal bas 'od chags pa ltar tshul khrims rnam par dag pas sems dpa' de dag gi mdangs rnam par mdzes so/ /

Just like an autumn moon unhindered by clouds, these bodhisattvas, who are pure, without the stains of faulty discipline, always control their sense faculties. Thus they are peaceful, like a vividly radiant light that beautifies their pure discipline.
gnyis pa shes rab kyis tshul khrims rnam par dag tshul la/

2.2.2.1.1.2.1.2.2.2. THE TEACHING ON HOW THE DISCIPLINE OF THE VICTORS’ HEIRS IS FREE OF CLINGING TO THINGS
de phyir de ni rtag tu gsum char la'ang*/ / gnyis blo'i rgyu ba yang dag bral bar 'gyur/ /
Therefore, these bodhisattvas are always perfectly free Of the movement of dualistic mind toward the three spheres. (2.3cd)

zhes pas bstan/ des na tshul khrims dag pa de'i phyir ram ched du dri med la gnas pa'i rgyal sras de ni rtag tu gzhi gang la dang*/ gang zhig dang*/ gang gis spong ba'i 'khor gsum char la yang dngos po dang dngos med sogs gnyis blo'i rgyu ba dang yang dag bral bar 'gyur ro/ /

Therefore, since their discipline is pure, the heirs of the victorious ones who abide on The Stainless are always perfectly free of the movement of the dualistic mind, which clings to things and nonthings, along with its movement toward the three spheres—the object toward which the discipline is aimed, the discipline itself, and the person who performs the discipline by refraining from a negative action.

spyir tshul khrims kyi bsngags pa dang*/ bye brag tu byang sems kyi tshul khrims kyi bsngags pa dang*/ 'jig rten dang 'jig rten las 'das pa'i rnam dbye bstan pa'o/ /

tshul khrims 'chal ba'i nyes dmigs dang/ tshul khrims kyi yon tan bstan pa gnyis/ /

sbyin pa'i 'bras bu mi rdzogs pa dang*/ ngan song las mi thar ba'i skyon no/ /
2.2.2.1.1.2.2.1.1.1. How the results of generosity will be exhausted 2.2.2.1.1.2.2.1.1.2. The fault of not being able to gain liberation from the lower realms
dang po la/
2.2.2.1.1.2.2.1.1.1. HOW THE RESULTS OF GENEROSITY WILL BE EXHAUSTED
ngan song du ltung ba dang*/ sbyin pa'i 'bras bu mi rdzogs pa dngos so/ /
2.2.2.1.1.2.2.1.1.1.1. How one falls to the lower realms 2.2.2.1.1.2.2.1.1.1.2. The actual teaching on how the results of generosity will be exhausted
dang po ni/
2.2.2.1.1.2.2.1.1.1.1. HOW ONE FALLS TO THE LOWER REALMS
sbyin pas longs spyod dag ni 'gro ngan na'ang*/ / skye bo tshul khrims rkang pa nyams las 'byung*/ /
Having enjoyments, yet in the lower realms, Comes about due to the degeneration of the legs of discipline. (2.4ab)

zhes pas bstan/ tshul khrims ni sbyin pa las 'bras bu che zhing yon tan gyi rten du bstan pa yin te/ sbyin pas sbyin bdag tshul khrims dang ldan na lha mi'i nang du longs spyod phun tshogs 'byung ba dag ni de las bzlog ste gtong yang tshul dang mi mthun pas ngan 'gro na'ang klu sogs kyi skye bo longs spyod 'byor ba ni tshul khrims rkang pa nyams pa la'ang 'byung ba'i phyir/

It is taught that discipline yields greater results than generosity and is the support for all good qualities. This is so because if someone practices generosity while keeping good discipline, they will experience a wealth of enjoyments as a god or human. However, if one gives in a way that does not harmonize with discipline, one will receive enjoyments, yet they will be experienced in the lower realms, in a birth as a nāga and so on. This comes about due to the degeneration of the legs of discipline.
gnyis pa (sbyin pa'i 'bras bu mi rdzogs pa dngos )ni/
2.2.2.1.1.2.2.1.1.1.2. THE ACTUAL TEACHING ON HOW THE RESULTS OF GENEROSITY WILL BE EXHAUSTED
bskyed bcas dngos 'du yongs su zad pas na/ / phyin chad de la longs spyod 'byung mi 'gyur/ /
When both capital and interest become exhausted, One will not receive enjoyments again. (2.4cd)

zhes pas bstan/ tshul mi ldan gyi gtong po ngan song ba de la sbyin 'bras rgyun bcas su 'byung ngam zhe na/ mi 'byung ste/ de lta'i gang zag de tshe snga mar lha mi'i rten la sbyin pa btang ba'i 'bras bu bskyed dang bcas pa dngos po'i 'du ba sbyin pa'i sa bon dang bcas pa ngan song gi rten la yongs su zad pas na phyin chad ngan song gi rten de la dge blo sgrub pa ches nyung bas sbyin 'bras longs spyod rgyun mi chad 'byung bar mi 'gyur ba'i phyir ro/ /

Will someone in the lower realms who has given without discipline still experience a continual stream of the results of their generosity? No, they will not. When the capital, the results of the generosity that they practiced in a god or human body, and the interest, the seed of generosity, become exhausted, they will not enjoy an uninterrupted stream of enjoyments as the result of generosity again. For, it is extremely rare for a being born in the lower realms to develop an aspiration towards virtuous activity.
gnyis pa ngan song las mi thar ba'i skyon ni/
2.2.2.1.1.2.2.1.1.2. THE FAULT OF NOT BEING ABLE TO GAIN LIBERATION FROM THE LOWER REALMS
gang tshe rang dbang 'jug cing mthun gnas pa/ / gal te 'di bdag 'dzin par mi byed na/ / g.yang sar lhung bas gzhan dbang 'jug 'gyur pa/ / de las phyi nas gang gis slong bar 'gyur/ /
At the time when one has freedom and favorable conditions, If one does not protect oneself, One will later fall into an abyss deprived of freedom. Who will lift one up from that state then? (2.5)

zhes pas bstan/ tshul dang bral na phyin chad longs spyod mi 'byung bar ma zad ngan 'gro las thar pa'ang ches dka' ste/ dal 'byor dang ldan pa gang gi tshe dpa' bo mthun pa'i yul na 'jigs pa kun dang grol ba ltar lha mi'i 'gro bar gzhan la rag ma las par dge ba la rang dbang du 'jug cing mthun par gnas pas gal te skye bo 'di dag tshul khrims sogs kyi legs spyad kyis bdag nyid ngan 'gror sogs las 'dzin par mi byed na dpa' bo lcags sgrog gis bcings nas ri sul du bskyur ba ltar ngan 'gro'i g.yang sar lhung bas/ las nyon gyi gzhan dbang gis ngan 'gror 'jug par 'gyur ba na ngan song de las phyi nas gang gis slong bar 'gyur te/ mi 'gyur ba'i phyir te/ las ngan gyi 'bras bu ma zad par btsan thar mi srid pa dang*/ de dag gis de nas thar thabs la mi brtson pa'i phyir/ gal te mir skyes kyang tshe thung ba dang bde 'gro'i las mi rtsom mo/ /

Without discipline, not only will one not obtain enjoyments in the future, it will also be extremely difficult to gain liberation from the lower realms. At the time when one has the freedoms and advantages [of a precious human birth], one is like a warrior free from fear in a safe land. As a god or human, one does not need to depend upon others, but has the freedom and favorable conditions needed to practice virtue. If beings in these situations do not protect themselves from the lower realms through the excellent conduct of discipline and so on, they will become like warriors bound by iron chains and cast away into mountain ravines: they will fall into the abyss of the lower realms. There they will be deprived of freedom and subject to karma and mental afflictions. Who will lift them out of the lower realms then? No one will, because it is impossible to gain freedom from the prison of negative karma unless the results of that karma have been exhausted. Furthermore, beings of the lower realms are not inclined to exert themselves in methods for attaining liberation. Even if one manages to take a human birth, one’s life will be short, and one will not accumulate the karma of the pleasant existences.
gnyis pa tshul khrims kyi yon tan bstan pa la/
2.2.2.1.1.2.2.1.2. THE EXCELLENT QUALITIES OF DISCIPLINE
sbyin pa'i 'og tu tshul khrims kyi gtam mdzad pa'i rgyu mtshan/ tshul khrims yon tan kun gyi rten du bstan pa/ skye 'phags kyi mngon mtho nges legs kyi rgyur bstan pa gsum/

2.2.2.1.1.2.2.1.2.1. The reason for the Buddha’s teaching discipline after generosity 2.2.2.1.1.2.2.1.2.2. Discipline is the support for all good qualities 2.2.2.1.1.2.2.1.2.3. Discipline is the cause of the higher realms and the definite good for both ordinary and noble beings
dang po ni/
2.2.2.1.1.2.2.1.2.1. THE REASON FOR THE BUDDHA’S TEACHING DISCIPLINE AFTER GENEROSITY
de phyir rgyal bas sbyin pa'i gtam mdzad nas/ / tshul khrims rjes 'gro'i gtam nyid mdzad pa yin/ /
Therefore, the Victorious One followed his teaching on generosity With the teaching on discipline. (2.6ab)

zhes pas bstan/ 'chal tshul gyis sbyin 'bras chud gsan pa sogs nyes pa mang ba bskyed pa de'i phyir/ rgyal bas sbyin pa'i gtam mdzad nas de'i 'og tu sbyin 'bras gong 'phel du byed pa ni tshul khrims kyi rjes su 'gro bas de'i gtam nyid la bsngags pa mdzad pa yin no/ /

Faulty discipline produces many undesirables, such as meager results arising from generosity. Therefore, because discipline is what causes the results of generosity to flourish, the Victorious One followed his teachings on generosity with teachings in praise of discipline.
gnyis pa (tshul khrims yon tan kun gyi rten du bstan pa )ni/
2.2.2.1.1.2.2.1.2.2. DISCIPLINE IS THE SUPPORT FOR ALL GOOD QUALITIES
yon tan tshul khrims zhing du rnam 'phel na/ / 'bras bu nyer spyod chad pa med par 'gyur/ /
By growing the seeds of qualities on the field of discipline, The enjoyment of their fruits will never cease. (2.6cd)

zhes pas bstan/ de ni yon tan gyi rten nyid yin pa'i phyir tshul khrims kyi zhing du sbyin sogs kyi sa bon btab pas yon tan rnams rnam par 'phel ba na 'bras bu longs spyad bya nyer spyod chad pa med par 'gyur ro/ /

Since discipline is the support for all good qualities, if on its field one plants the seeds of qualities (generosity and so on), when those seeds grow, the enjoyment of the fruits they bear will never cease.
gsum pa (skye 'phags kyi mngon mtho nges legs kyi rgyur bstan pa )ni/
2.2.2.1.1.2.2.1.2.3. DISCIPLINE IS THE CAUSE OF THE HIGHER REALMS AND THE DEFINITE GOOD FOR BOTH ORDINARY AND NOBLE BEINGS
so so'i skye bo rnams dang gsung skyes dang*/ / rang byang chub la bdag nyid nges rnams dang*/ / rgyal sras rnams kyi nges par legs pa dang*/ / mngon mtho'i rgyu ni tshul khrims las gzhan med/ /

For ordinary beings, those born of the victors’ speech, Those set on solitary enlightenment, And heirs of the victors, the cause of definite goodness And the higher realms is none other than discipline. (2.7)

ces pas bstan/ so so'i skye bo rnams dang gsung skyes nyan thos dang rang byang chub la bdag nyid nges pa rang rgyal rnams dang rgyal sras byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyi nges par legs pa thar pa dang mngon mtho 'khor ba'i bde ba thob pa'i rgyu ni/ sa gnyis pa'i yon tan la gtso bor bsngags pa'i skabs 'dir tshul khrims las khyad par du 'phags pa gzhan med de/ de gnyis kyi rgyu ni skabs 'dir tshul khrims mchog yin pa'i phyir/

For ordinary beings, the hearers born of the victors’ speech, the solitary realizers set on their own enlightenment, and the bodhisattva heirs of the victorious ones, the liberation of definite goodness and the happiness of saṃsāra that comprises the higher realms are both, in this context of praising discipline as foremost, caused by discipline, the main quality of the second bodhisattva ground. There is no quality superior to discipline, because discipline is supreme among all qualities in terms of being the cause of [definite goodness and the higher realms].
gnyis pa bye brag tu byang sems kyi tshul khrims kyi bsngags pa ni/
2.2.2.1.1.2.2.2. THE PARTICULAR PRAISE OF THE DISCIPLINE OF BODHISATTVAS
ji ltar rgya mtsho ro dang lhan cig dang*/ / bkra shis sna nag ma dang lhan cig bzhin/ / de ltar tshul khrims dbang byas bdag nyid che/ / de 'chal ba dang lhan cig gnas mi 'dod/ /

Just as an ocean and a corpse do not remain together, And just as something auspicious and inauspicious cannot coexist, The great being who masters discipline Does not remain together with depraved ethics. (2.8)

ces pas bstan/ ji ltar rgya mtsho chen po ro dang lhan cig zhag tu mi gnas pa dang*/ bkra shis dang bkra ma shis sna nag ma dang lhan cig mi gnas pa bzhin gong du bshad pa de ltar tshul khrims phun sum tshogs pa'i dbang du byed pa'i bdag nyid chen po sa 'dir gnas pa de 'chal pa'i tshul khrims dang lhan cig gnas par mi 'dod do/ /

A great ocean cannot co-abide with a corpse,[168] and something auspicious cannot also be something inauspicious. In the same way, the great being of this ground, who has mastered the excellent qualities of discipline explained above, will not remain together with depraved ethics.
gsum pa 'jig rten dang 'jig rten las 'das pa'i rnam dbye bstan pa ni/
2.2.2.1.1.2.2.3. THE CLASSIFICATIONS OF MUNDANE AND TRANSCENDENT DISCIPLINE
gang gis gang zhig gang la spong byed pa/ / gsum du dmigs pa yod na tshul khrims de/ / 'jig rten pa yi pha rol phyin ces bshad/ / gsum la chags pas stong de 'jig rten 'das/ /

If discipline involves observing the three spheres— The relinquisher, the thing relinquished, and the being toward whom the relinquishing is performed— That discipline is taught as a mundane perfection. Discipline empty of attachment to those three is transcendent. (2.9)

zhes pas bstan/ gang zag gang gis spang bya gang zhig gzhi sems can gang la spong bar byed pa gsum du dngos por dmigs pa yod na tshul khrims de ni 'jig rten pa'i pha rol tu phyin pa'o zhes mdo las bshad do/ / tshul khrims de sher phyin gyis zin pas 'khor gsum la chags pas stong pa de ni 'jig rten 'das pa'i pha rol phyin ces bya'o/ /

It was taught in the sūtras that if discipline involves observing the three spheres—the individual doing the relinquishing, the thing relinquished, and the sentient being with respect to whom the relinquishing takes place—that discipline will be a mundane perfection. The discipline that has been embraced by supreme knowledge and is therefore empty of attachment to the three spheres is known as a transcendent perfection.
gsum pa sa'i nges tshig dang rnam smin dang yon tan brjod de mjug bsdu ba ni/
2.2.2.1.1.2.3. THE SUMMARY THAT DESCRIBES THE PRECISE MEANING, RIPENING, AND QUALITIES OF THE GROUND

rgyal sras zla ba las byung srid min srid pa yi/ / dpal gyur dri ma dang bral dri ma med 'di yang*/ / ston ka'i dus kyi zla ba'i 'od ni ji bzhin du/ / 'gro ba'i yid kyi gdung ba sel bar byed pa yin/ /
dbu ma la 'jug pa las sems bskyed pa gnyis pa'o/ /

These heirs of the Victor, born of the moon, are not of cyclic existence, yet they are the glory of cyclic existence. They are immaculate; this stainless ground, Like the light of an autumn moon, Dispels agony from the minds of beings. (2.10)
This completes the second bodhichitta generation from the Entrance to the Middle Way.

zhes pas bstan/ sa 'dir gnas kyi rgyal sras zla ba las byung ba 'khor bar ma gtogs pas srid pa min kyang yon tan phun sum tshogs pas gling bzhi'i dbang phyug phun sum tshogs pa'i rgyu yin pa'i phyir srid pa'i dpal du gyur pa 'chal ba'i dri ma dang bral dri ma med pa 'di yang ji ltar ston ka'i dus kyi zla ba'i 'od dri bral gyis ni skye bo'i gdung ba sel ba ji bzhin du 'gro ba'i 'chal tshul gyi yid kyi gdung ba sel bar byed pa yin no/ /

The heirs of the victorious ones on this bodhisattva ground are born of the moon. Since they are not within the domain of saṃsāra, they are not of cyclic existence (sipa/srid pa), yet because of their abundant qualities they possess the causes for taking birth as the sovereigns of all four continents. Therefore, they are the glory of cyclic existence. They are immaculate, free of the stains of faulty discipline. This stainlessness is like the light of an autumn moon: just as it dispels the agony of beings, so the bodhisattva dispels the agony of faulty discipline from the minds of beings.
dbu ma la 'jug pa las dri ma med pa zhes bya ba sems bskyed pa gnyis pa'i bshad pa'o// //
This completes the explanation of the second bodhichitta generation, known as The Stainless, from the Entrance to the Middle Way.

khyad gzhi sa'i ngo bo mdor bstan/ khyad chos sa'i yon tan rgyas par bshad/ sa'i yon tan brjod de mjug bsdu ba'o/ /

2.2.2.1.1.3.1. THE BRIEF TEACHING ON THE ESSENCE OF THE GROUND, THE BASIS OF ITS FEATURES
shes bya'i bud shing ma lus sreg pa'i me'i/ / 'od 'byung phyir na sa ni gsum pa 'di/ / 'od byed pa ste bde gshegs sras po la/ / de tshe nyi ltar zangs 'dra'i snang ba 'byung*/ /

Since the light of the fire that burns All the kindling of knowable objects arises On this third ground, it is called The Luminous. At that time, a brilliance like the sun or like copper dawns in the heirs of the sugatas. (3.1)

zhes pas bstan/ shes bya'i bud shing ma lus sreg par byed pa'i ye shes kyi me'i 'od 'byung ba'i phyir na sems bskyed gsum pa thob pa'i sems dpa'i sa ni gsum pa 'di la 'od byed pa zhes bya ste/ de lta'i bder gshegs sras po de la de tshe ye shes kyi snang ba ni nyi ma 'char ka ltar zangs 'dra'i snang ba 'byung ba'i phyir/ /

Here the fire or light of wisdom that burns all the kindling of knowable objects without exception arises. Therefore this ground, where the third level of bodhichitta is generated, is called The Luminous, because at that time the brilliance of the wisdom of the heirs of the sugatas is like the rising sun or like copper.
gnyis pa (khyad chos sa'i yon tan rgyas par bshad pa )la/

2.2.2.1.1.3.2.1.1. HOW PATIENCE IS FOREMOST ON THIS GROUND
snying rjes bzod pa dang*/ shes rab kyis bzod pa'o/ /

2.2.2.1.1.3.2.1.1.1. PATIENCE BY WAY OF COMPASSION
gal te gnas min 'khrug pa 'ga' yis de'i/ / lus las sha ni rus bcas yun ring du/ / srang re re nas bcad par gyur kyang de'i/ / bzod pa gcod par byed la lhag par skye/ /

If someone, through unwarranted anger, Cut the flesh and bones from the body of a bodhisattva For a long time, ounce by ounce, The bodhisattva would engender patience, especially for the one who is cutting. (3.2)

zhes pas bstan/ sems dpa' de ni khro ba'i skabs dbye ba min te/ bshad ma thag pa'i yon tan dang ldan zhing gzhan sems srung ba la kun nas mnar sems dgus kun nas bslangs te sgo gsum gyis gzhan la gnod pa byed pa mi srid pa'i phyir/ des na gal te khong khro bskyed pa'i gnas min pa'i sems dpa' la sems khong nas 'khrug pa'i skye bo 'ga' yis sems dpa' de'i lus las sha ni rus bcas yun ring du gcod cing de'ang srang re re nas sdod cing sdod cing bcad par gyur kyang sems dpa' de'i bzod pa ni gcod par byed la lhag par skye ba yin te/ byang sems kyis sdig pa'i las can gyi sdug bsngal la lhag par dmigs pa'i phyir/

There is no time during which these bodhisattvas become angry, because they possess the excellent qualities that have been explained above, and because it is impossible for them to inflict harm on others through the actions of their three gates. When sustaining their altruistic attitude they are not motivated by any of the nine forms of tormented mind.[169] Therefore, if someone who was deeply agitated cut flesh and bones from the body of a bodhisattva, who is not an appropriate object of anger, for a long time, and moreover cut away methodically, ounce by ounce, the bodhisattva would still engender patience (kṣhānti, zöpa/bzod pa), especially for the one who is cutting, because bodhisattvas pay close attention to the suffering of beings who possess the karma of negative actions.
gnyis pa (shes rab kyis bzod pa )ni/
2.2.2.1.1.3.2.1.1.2. PATIENCE BY WAY OF SUPREME KNOWLEDGE
bdag med mthong ba'i byang chub sems dpa' la/ / gang zhig gang gis gang tshe ji ltar gcod/ / gang phyir chos kyang de yis gzugs brnyan ltar/ / mthong ba des kyang de yis bzod par 'gyur/ /

For bodhisattvas who see selflessness, All phenomena—what is cut, the cutter, the time of the cutting, the method of cutting, and so on— Are seen to be a like a reflection. Therefore they have patience. (3.3)

zhes pas bstan/ de ltar bzod par ma zad chos thams cad bdag med par mthong ba'i byang chub sems dpa' la bcad bya sha rus gang zhig gcod po gang gis dus gang gi tshe mtshon sogs kyis ji ltar gcod kyang sems dpa' des bzod de/ rgyu mtshan gang gi phyir na/ 'khor gsum gyi chos thams cad kyang sems dpa' de yis gzugs brnyan ltar bdag dang bdag gi dang bral bar rang bzhin med par mthong ba des na sems dpa' de yis bzod par 'gyur ba yin no/ /

Not only do the bodhisattvas have the patience described above, for a bodhisattva who sees all phenomena as selfless, the flesh and bones that are cut, along with the cutter, the time of the cutting, and the weapon used to do the cutting are met with patience. Why? Because the bodhisattvas see all phenomena of the three spheres to be like reflections—free of self and entities connected to the self and free of inherent nature. For this reason, the bodhisattvas have patience.
gnyis pa zhar la bzod pa'i bsngags pa bshad pa la/

dang po la/
2.2.2.1.1.3.2.1.2.1. THE SHORTCOMINGS OF ANGER
'jig rten 'dir don med pa/ 'jig rten pha rol dang 'gal ba/ 'di dang pha rol gyi nyes dmigs gzhan yang bstan pa'o/ /

2.2.2.1.1.3.2.1.2.1.1. Anger is pointless in this world 2.2.2.1.1.3.2.1.2.1.2. Anger is contradictory to the aims of the next world 2.2.2.1.1.3.2.1.2.1.3. Further shortcomings connected to this life and the next
dang po ni/
2.2.2.1.1.3.2.1.2.1.1. ANGER IS POINTLESS IN THIS WORLD
gnod pa byas pas gal te der bkon na/ / de la bkon pas byas zin ldog gam ci/ / de phyir der bkon nges par 'dir don med/ / 'jig rten pha rol dang yang 'gal bar 'gyur/ /

If you get angry at someone who does you harm, Does your anger reverse what has already been done? Therefore, anger is definitely pointless in this life And is contradictory to one’s aims in future lives as well. (3.4)

zhes pas bstan/ bzod pa ni sems dpas nyams su len byar ma zad skye bo gzhan gyi'ang nyams su len rigs shing bdag la pha rol gyis gnod pa byas pas gal te gnod byed der zhe 'kham pa ste rkam par bkon na/ da de la bdag gis zhe bkon pas bdag lus la rma sogs byas zin gyi gnod pa zlog gam ci ste mi zlog pa de'i phyir gnod byed der zhe bkon pa khro ba ni nges par tshe 'dir yang don med de/ bya rgyu sngar byas zin pa'i phyir/ der ma zad de la der bkon na 'jig rten pha rol gyi bde ba sgrub pa dang yang ni 'gal bar 'gyur te/ khong khro skyes pas rnam smin yid mi 'ong 'phen pa'i phyir/

Patience is not only something to be practiced by bodhisattvas, it is also a most appropriate practice for other beings. If one gets angry at another person who has done one harm, does the anger toward them reverse the harm already done, such as the wounds on one’s body? No, it does not. Therefore, being resentful and angry toward someone who does one harm is definitely pointless in this life, because the harmful action has already been committed. Not only that, if one holds on to anger towards someone who does one harm, this will also be contradictory to the aim of accomplishing happiness for future lives, because the cause of engendering anger ripens into unpleasant results.
gnyis pa ('jig rten pha rol dang 'gal ba )la/
2.2.2.1.1.3.2.1.2.1.2. ANGER IS CONTRADICTORY TO THE AIMS OF THE NEXT WORLD
rnam smin yid du mi 'ong ba 'phen pa dang*/ yun ring bsags pa'i bsod nams zad pa'i rgyur bstan pa gnyis/
2.2.2.1.1.3.2.1.2.1.2.1. Anger ripens into unpleasant results 2.2.2.1.1.3.2.1.2.1.2.2. Anger is the cause for the exhaustion of long-accumulated merit
dang po ni/
2.2.2.1.1.3.2.1.2.1.2.1. ANGER RIPENS INTO UNPLEASANT RESULTS

sngon byas pa yi mi dge'i las kyi 'bras bu gang*/ / zad par byed par brjod par 'dod pa de nyid ko/ / gzhan la gnod pa dang ni khro bas sdug bsngal phyir/ / sa bon nyid du ji lta bur na 'khrid par byed/ /

Patience is the very thing that is asserted To exhaust the results of previously committed nonvirtuous actions. Since harming and being angry toward others causes them suffering, Why lead yourself to the lower realms by planting such a seed? (3.5)

ces pas bstan/ mtshon rnon po 'debs pa'i dgra la bzod par rigs te/ rang gis sngon srog gcod byas pa'i mi dge'i las kyi 'bras bu ngan song du rnam smin dang 'dir rgyu mthun smin pa gang la bzod par byas pas las 'bras zad par byed par brjod par 'dod pa de nyid ko'i phyir/ / gnod byed gzhan la bdag nyid kyis gnod pa dang ni khro bas sdug bsngal bar byed pa'i phyir gnod byed la bzod pa ma bsgom par de'i lan du gnod pa byed na rang nyid la rang gis slar gnod pa'i nye bar len pa'i rgyu nyid kyis ngan song du ji lta bur na 'khrid par byed pa ni mi rigs te/ dper na sman pas nad gso ba'i phyir btsags cha rnon pos rma 'byin pa la bzod pa bzhin du sdig pa dag byed kyi sdug bsngal la bzod pa sgom par rigs so/ /

It is reasonable to have patience toward an enemy who stabs you with a sharp weapon. [For the stabbing is undoubtedly a result of your own past actions]—the result of one’s own previous nonvirtuous actions of killing ripen as rebirth in the lower realms, and they also ripen in a causally concordant way in this life. It is asserted that patience toward these situations is the very thing that exhausts such karmic results. Since harming and being angry at another who has caused you harm make them suffer in turn, if instead of cultivating patience toward the aggressor one responds by harming them more, one plants the seed for bringing harm again upon oneself. This will lead one to the lower realms. Why would one do that? That would not be reasonable. Just as it is reasonable to have patience toward a doctor who uses sharp instruments in order to heal one’s illnesses by removing the source of a wound, it is also reasonable to cultivate patience toward the suffering that purifies negative actions.
gnyis pa (yun ring bsags pa'i bsod nams zad pa'i rgyur bstan pa )ni/
2.2.2.1.1.3.2.1.2.1.2.2. ANGER IS THE CAUSE FOR THE EXHAUSTION OF LONG-ACCUMULATED MERIT
gang phyir rgyal sras rnams la khros pa yis/ / sbyin dang khrims byung dge ba bskal pa brgyar/ / bsags pa skad cig gis 'joms de yi phyir/ / mi bzod las gzhan sdig pa yod ma yin/ /

Anger toward heirs of the victorious ones Destroys, in a single instant, the merit accumulated Through generosity and discipline during a hundred eons. Therefore, there is no greater misdeed than impatience. (3.6)

zhes pas bstan/ mi bzod pa ni rnam smin sdug bsngal bskyed par ma zad/ rang gis ches yun du bsags pa'i dge rtsa yang zad byed yin te/ gang gi phyir sems dpa' des gzhan rgyal sras rnams la sems dpar shes ma shes gang yang rung bas nyon mongs pa'i dbang gis bden pa'am rdzun pa'i nyes pa sgro btags nas khros pa yi bsam pa skad cig gis kyang sbyin dang khrims byung dge ba bskal pa brgyar bsags pa dus skad cig gis 'joms pa de'i phyir ro/ / mdor na mi bzod pa las gzhan sdig pa che ba yod pa ma yin te sdug bsngal cher bskyed cing dge ba la gnod par byed pa'i sdig pa yin pa'i phyir/

Not only does impatience ripen into suffering, it also causes the exhaustion of the roots of virtue one has accumulated for a very long time. If a bodhisattva, governed by mental afflictions, imputes a fault that is either true or false upon another bodhisattva, then, regardless of whether they knew that other person was a bodhisattva or not, this single instant of angry thinking will, right then and there, destroy the merit they had accumulated through generosity and discipline during a hundred eons. Therefore there is no greater misdeed than impatience, because impatience produces intense suffering and does great harm to virtue.
gsum pa 'di dang pha rol gyi nyes dmigs gzhan yang bstan pa ni/
2.2.2.1.1.3.2.1.2.1.3. FURTHER SHORTCOMINGS CONNECTED TO THIS LIFE AND THE NEXT
mi sdug gzugs su byed cing dam pa min par bkri/ / tshul dang tshul min shes pa'i rnam dpyod 'phrog byed cing*/ / mi bzod pa yis myur du ngan 'gror skyur bar byed/ /

Impatience makes one unattractive and casts one in bad company. It steals the intelligence that distinguishes between proper and improper discipline, And quickly propels one to the lower realms. (3.7abc)

ces pas bstan/ bzod par mi byed kyang gzhan la gnod mi nus pas ni bdag kho na 'joms la/ nus pas ni rang gzhan gnyis ka 'joms par byed pa ste khro gnyer sdud pa sogs mi sdug pa'i gzugs su byed cing mtshon cha sogs len pa la 'jug pas dam pa min par bkri ba dang khro bas non te blang dor la rmongs nas tshul dang tshul min shes pa'i rnam dpyod 'phrog par byed pa ni mthong chos kyi nyes pa yin cing srog 'gag pa na mi bzod pa yi las des rang nyid myur du ngan 'gror skyur bar byed do/ /

If one loses patience yet does not have the ability to harm others, it will only be oneself who is defeated. However, if one is capable of harming others, one destroys both oneself and others. Impatience makes one unattractive—it produces tight wrinkles that come from frowning and other undesirable appearances. It casts one in bad company[170] because of one’s engaging in behavior such as appropriating weapons. Because of being submerged in anger, one becomes ignorant regarding what to adopt or reject. Impatience steals away the intelligence that distinguishes between proper and improper discipline. All of these are results of impatience that are observable in this life. When one’s life force is exhausted, the karma of one’s impatience will quickly propel one to the lower realms.
gnyis pa bzod pa'i phan yon ni/
2.2.2.1.1.3.2.1.2.2. THE BENEFITS OF PATIENCE

bzod pas bshad zin dang 'gal yon tan rnams byed do/ / bzod pas mdzes shing skye bo dam pa la/ / phangs dang lugs dang lugs min shes pa la/ / mkhas par 'gyur zhing de yi 'og tu ni/ / lha mir skye dang sdig pa zad par 'gyur/ /

Patience produces the opposite qualities to those just explained— (3.7d) Patience makes one beautiful, connects one with genuine beings, And gives one skill in distinguishing between What is proper and improper. Later, one will take birth as a god or human and see the exhaustion of misdeeds. (3.8)

zhes pas bstan/ mi bzod pa la skyon de ltar na bzod pa'i yon tan ni gang zhe na/ bzod pas mi sdug pa sogs bshad zin dang 'gal ba'i yon tan rnams bskyed par byed do/ / yon tan gang zhe na/ tshe 'dir bzod pas gzugs mthong ma thag mdzes shing gzhan dad pa skye ba dang*/ gshe yang slar mi gshe ba sogs kyis skye bo dam pa rnams la 'phangs pa ste dam par rtogs pas gzhan dag gis dwang bas gus par 'dzin par byed pa dang*/ lugs te rigs pa dang lugs min pa rigs pa ma yin pa shes pa la mkhas par 'gyur zhing tshe de yi 'og tu ni lha mir skye ba dang dge ba 'phel zhing sdig pa zad par 'gyur ro/ /

If impatience entails such faults, then what are the benefits of patience? Patience produces the qualities opposite to those just explained, the unattractive form and others. What specifically are these qualities? For this life, patience makes one appear beautiful the moment one is beheld by others, causing others to have faith in one. Through not returning harm for harm done, one will become connected with genuine beings. Through recognizing the genuineness of these beings, one will also be able to cause others to have reverence and respect for them. One will become skilled in distinguishing between what ways are proper and what ways are improper. After this life, one will take birth as a god or human and see the increase of one’s virtue and the exhaustion of one’s misdeeds.
gsum pa khong khro ba spangs te bzod pa sgom par gdams pa ni/
2.2.2.1.1.3.2.1.2.3. THE INSTRUCTION TO THEREFORE RELINQUISH ANGER AND CULTIVATE PATIENCE
so so'i skye bo dang ni rgyal sras kyis/ / khro dang bzod pa'i skyon yon rig byas te/ mi bzod spangs nas 'phags pa'i skye bo yis/ / bsngags pa'i bzod pa rtag tu myur bsten bya/ /

Ordinary beings and heirs of the victors, Recognizing the faults of anger and the benefits of patience, Should relinquish impatience and always quickly hold to The patience praised by the noble ones. (3.9)

zhes pas bstan/ so so'i skye bo dang ni rgyal sras kyis khro dang bzod pa'i skyon yon rig par byas te mi bzod pa spangs nas 'phags pa'i skye bo yis bsngags pa'i bzod pa dus rtag tu myur du bsten par bya'o/ /

Ordinary beings and heirs of the victorious ones, recognizing the faults of anger and the benefits of patience, should relinquish impatience and always quickly hold to the patience praised by the noble ones.
gsum pa 'jig rten las 'das ma 'das kyi rnam dbye bstan pa ni/
2.2.2.1.1.3.2.1.3. THE CLASSIFICATIONS OF TRANSCENDENT AND MUNDANE PATIENCE
rdzogs sangs rgyas kyi byang chub phyir bsngos kyang*/ / gsum dmigs yod na de ni 'jig rten pa'o/ / dmigs pa med na de nyid sangs rgyas kyis/ / 'jig rten 'das pa'i pha rol phyin ces bstan/ /

Even if one’s patience is dedicated to the enlightenment of perfect buddhahood, If it entails observation of the three spheres, it is a mundane perfection. If it is free from such observation, the Buddha has taught Such patience to be a transcendent perfection. (3.10)

zhes pas bstan/ bzod pa gang rdzogs sangs rgyas kyi byang chub kyi phyir bsngos kyang gang bzod pa/ gang gis bzod pa/ sems can gang la bzod pa ste 'khor gsum la dmigs pa yod na de ni 'jig rten pa'i bzod pa'i pha rol tu phyin pa'o/ / 'khor gsum du dmigs pa med na de nyid sangs rgyas kyis 'jig rten las 'das pa'i pha rol phyin ces bstan to/ /

Even if one’s patience is dedicated to the enlightenment of perfect buddhahood, if it entails observation of the three spheres—what is tolerated, the person tolerating, and the sentient being toward whom the tolerance is engendered—that perfection is a mundane perfection of patience. If it is free from observation of the three spheres, the Buddha has taught such patience to be a transcendent perfection.
gnyis pa spangs rtogs phrin las kyi yon tan gzhan bstan pa ni/
2.2.2.1.1.3.2.2. THE OTHER QUALITIES OF RELINQUISHMENT, REALIZATION, AND ACTIVITY
sa der rgyal sras bsam gtan mngon shes dang*/ / 'dod chags zhe sdang yongs su zad par 'gyur/ / des kyang rtag tu 'jig rten pa yi ni/ / 'dod pa'i 'dod chags 'joms par nus par 'gyur/ /

On this ground, the bodhisattvas gain the concentrations and higher cognitions, And completely exhaust attachment and aggression. They also become capable of continually Conquering worldly attachment toward desirables. (3.11)

zhes pas bstan/ sa gsum pa der rgyal sras bzod pa'i phar phyin dag pa de bzhin bsam gtan bzhi dang gzugs med pa'i snyoms 'jug bzhi dang tshad med bzhi dang mngon shes lnga dang ldan pa ni rtogs pa'i yon tan dang rten 'brel 'pho ba med pa dang rnam par 'jig pa med par rtogs pas 'dod chags zhe sdang gti mug bcas pa yongs su zad par 'gyur ba ni spangs pa'i yon tan yin la/ sa 'di'i sems dpa' ni rnam smin gyi dbang gis lha'i dbang por skye zhing des kyang rtag tu 'jig rten pa yi ni 'dod pa'i yon tan la sred pa'i 'dod chags 'joms par byed cing 'dod khams nas 'don nus par 'gyur ro/ /

On this third ground, as these heirs of the victorious ones purify the perfection of patience, they also gain the four concentrations,[171] the four absorptions of the formless realm,[172] the four limitless ones,[173] and the five higher cognitions.[174] All of these are qualities of realization. Through their realization of unmoving interdependence and the nondisintegration [of interdependence],[175] they completely exhaust attachment, aggression, and bewilderment. These are qualities of relinquishment. Due to the ripening of the karma of the bodhisattvas on this ground, they are capable of taking birth as the ruler of the gods, yet they continually conquer the mundane attachment of craving the desirables, the sense pleasures. Thus they gain the ability to extract themselves from the desire realm.
gsum pa phar phyin gyi rten dang tshogs dang 'bras bu'i rnam gzhag gzhan bstan pa ni/
2.2.2.1.1.3.2.3. THE SUPPORT FOR THIS PERFECTION, ITS CORRESPONDING ACCUMULATION, AND ITS RESULT
sbyin sogs chos gsum de dag phal mo che/ / bde bar gshegs pas khyim pa rnams la bsngags/ / bsod nams zhes bya'i tshogs kyang de dag nyid/ / sangs rgyas gzugs kyi bdag nyid sku yi rgyu/ /
The Sugata primarily taught The three dharmas of generosity and so on to laypeople. These three accomplish the accumulation of merit And are the causes for the buddhas’ form kāyas. (3.12)

zhes pas bstan/ da ni phar phyin dang po gsum gyi rten gyi khyad par dang tshogs kyi rang bzhin dang 'bras bu'i rnam gzhag gsal bar brjod par bya ste/ sems dpa' dag phyin drug gi rten can yin mod kyi 'on kyang byang sems khyim pa dang rab byung gi phyogs gnyis las sbyin pa sogs chos gsum po de dag phal mo che bde bar gshegs pas khyim pa rnams la bslab byar bsngags te/ des de dag bsgrub sla ba'i phyir/ rab byung la ni brtson bsam shes rab dag bslab byar bsngags te/ snga ma dag mi sgrub pa min kyang zhar byung gi tshul gyis yongs su rdzogs par byed pa'i phyir ro/ / sangs rgyas kyi rgyu tshogs gnyis las bsod nams zhes bya'i tshogs kyang phar phyin gsum po de dag nyid yin la/ ye shes kyi tshogs ni bsam gtan dang shes rab gnyis yin cing*/ brtson 'grus ni gnyis ka'i rgyu yin no/ / bsod nams kyi tshogs de ni sangs rgyas gzugs kyi bdag nyid kyi sku bsod nams brgyas mtshan pa'i rmad byung bsam gyis mi khyab pa'i rgyu dang*/ chos sku'i rgyu ni ye shes kyi tshogs so/ /

At this time Chandrakīrti clearly describes the third ground’s special support, the accumulation to which it corresponds, and the presentation of its result. All bodhisattvas possess the support for the practices of all six perfections, yet out of the two categories of laypeople and monastics, the Sugata primarily taught the three dharmas of generosity and so on[176] to laypeople by praising them as something in which they should train. He did so because these three are easier to practice than the others. For monastics, the Buddha praised diligence, concentration, and supreme knowledge as fields of training, not because the earlier perfections are not practiced, but because they will be brought to full completion simply as an incidental benefit of practicing the latter three. Of the two causes for buddhahood, the two accumulations, the accumulation of merit is accomplished by the first three perfections, and the accumulation of wisdom is accomplished by concentration and supreme knowledge. Diligence is a cause for both accumulations. The accumulation of merit serves as the cause for the supreme and inconceivable form kāyas of the buddhas, which are marked by one hundred merits.[177] The cause for the dharmakāya is the accumulation of wisdom.
gsum pa sa'i yon tan brjod de mjug bsdu ba ni/
2.2.2.1.1.3.3. THE SUMMARY STATING THE QUALITIES OF THE GROUND

rgyal ba'i sras po nyi ma la gnas 'od byed 'di/ / rang gtogs mun rnams dang po yang dag bsal byas nas/ / 'gro ba'i mun pa rnam par 'joms par mngon par 'dod/ / sa 'dir shin tu rno bar gyur kyang khro mi 'gyur/ /
dbu ma la 'jug pa las sems bskyed pa gsum pa'o/ /

Here the heirs of the victors who dwell in the sun of The Luminous First perfectly dispel their own darkness And then earnestly long to conquer the darkness of beings. Though on this ground they are very sharp, they do not get angry. (3.13)
This completes the third bodhichitta generation from the Entrance to the Middle Way.

zhes pas bstan/ rgyal ba'i sras po nyi ma'i dkyil 'khor lta bu la gnas pa'i sa gsum pa 'od byed pa 'di ni rang rgyud du gtogs pa ste/ rang rten la yod pa'i mi shes pa'i mun pa rnams dang por skye bzhin pa'i skabs su yang dag par bsal bar byas nas de'i 'og tu 'gro ba rnams kyis sa gsum pa thob pa'i gegs gyur gyi mun pa rnam par 'joms par mngon par 'dod do/ / sems pa de ni sa 'dir yon tan gyi gegs gyur gyi nyes pa'i mun pa sel bar byed pas nyi ma'i 'od zer ltar shes rab shin tu rno bar gyur kyang skyon ldan gyi skye bo la khro bar mi 'gyur te/ bzod pa la ches goms shing snying rjes rgyud brlan par byas pa'i phyir/

Here the heirs of the victorious ones abide on The Luminous, whose brilliance is like that of a sun disc. First, they perfectly dispel their own darkness, ignorance in their own mindstream, while it is arising. Then, they earnestly long to conquer the darkness of the obstructions that prevent beings from attaining the third ground. Through dispelling the darkness of faults that obscures this ground’s qualities, the bodhisattvas’ supreme knowledge becomes very sharp, like the rays of the sun. Nevertheless, they do not get angry at beings who have faults, because they have cultivated great patience and because their mindstreams have been moistened by compassion.
dbu ma la 'jug pa las 'od byed pa zhes bya ba ste sems bskyed pa gsum pa'i bshad pa'o// //
This concludes the explanation of the third bodhichitta generation, The Luminous, from the Entrance to the Middle Way.
⋮ Ground Four: The Radiant
bzhi pa 'od 'phro bshad pa la/
2.2.2.1.1.4. THE EXPLANATION OF THE RADIANT (Archiṣhmati, Ö Trowa/’od ‘phro ba)
brtson 'grus lhag pa'i sgo nas ngo bo mdor bstan/ sa'i ming don dang yon tan bstan pa gnyis/
2.2.2.1.1.4.1. The concise teaching on its essence by way of the preeminence of diligence 2.2.2.1.1.4.2. The teaching on the name, meaning, and qualities of the ground
dang po ni/
2.2.2.1.1.4.1. THE CONCISE TEACHING ON ITS ESSENCE BY WAY OF THE PREEMINENCE OF DILIGENCE
yon tan ma lus brtson 'grus rjes 'gro zhing*/ / bsod nams blo gros tshogs ni gnyis kyi rgyu/ / brtson 'grus gang du 'bar bar gyur pa yi/ / sa de bzhi pa 'od ni 'phro ba'o/ /
All good qualities without exception follow after diligence, The cause of the accumulations of both merit and knowledge. The ground on which diligence blazes Is the fourth, The Radiant. (4.1)

zhes pas bstan/ phar phyin dang po gsum las brtson 'grus kyi phar phyin lhag pa'i sgo nas sems bskyed bzhi pa bstan te/ 'jig rten las 'das ma 'das kyi yon tan ma lus pa ni brtson 'grus kyi rjes su 'gro zhing de med par 'byung ba min te/ dge las la mi spro na sbyin sogs la 'jug mi srid cing*/ spro ldan ni dge chos ma thob pa thob pa dang thob pa gong du rgyas par byed pa'i phyir/ des na bsod nams dang blo gros kyi tshogs ni gnyis kyi rgyu yang brtson 'grus nyid yin pa'i phyir na brtson 'grus de gang du 'bar zhing lhag par gyur pa yi sa de ni byang sems kyi sa bzhi pa 'od ni 'phro ba'o zhes brjod do/ /

This verse describes the fourth bodhichitta generation, showing how, over and above the first three perfections, diligence (vīrya, tsöndrü/brtson ’grus) is preeminent on this ground. All good qualities without exception, whether mundane or transcendent, follow after diligence and do not arise without it, because if one has no delight in virtuous activity, it is impossible to engage in generosity and the other virtues. Furthermore, if one has such delight, one will attain the virtuous qualities one has not attained while expanding those one has already attained. Since diligence is the cause for the accumulations of both merit and knowledge,[178] the ground on which diligence blazes and becomes preeminent is the fourth bodhisattva ground, the one called The Radiant.
gnyis pa (sa'i ming don dang yon tan bstan pa )la/
2.2.2.1.1.4.2. THE TEACHING ON THE NAME, MEANING, AND QUALITIES OF THE GROUND
rtogs pa'i yon tan gyi ming don dang*/ spangs pa'i yon tan bstan pa'o/ /
2.2.2.1.1.4.2.1. The name and meaning of the qualities of realization 2.2.2.1.1.4.2.2. The teaching on the qualities of relinquishment
dang po ni/
2.2.2.1.1.4.2.1. THE NAME AND MEANING OF THE QUALITIES OF REALIZATION
der ni bder gshegs sras la rdzogs pa yi/ / byang chub phyogs lhag bsgoms pa las skyes pa'i/ / snang ba zangs kyi 'od bas lhag 'byung zhing*/ /
On this ground, for the children of the Sugata There dawns a brilliance surpassing the glow of copper, Born from especially cultivating the factors of perfect enlightenment. (4.2abc)

zhes pas bstan/ sa bzhi pa der ni bder gshegs sras po de la rdzogs pa yi byang chub phyogs kyi chos so bdun lhag par bsgoms pa las skyes pa'i ye shes kyi snang ba sngar bshad kyi zangs kyi 'od dper byas pa bas lhag pa 'byung zhing rgyu mtshan de'i phyir sa der ye shes kyi me 'od 'phro bas 'od 'phro'i sar brjod do/ /

On this, the fourth, ground, for the children of the Sugata there dawns the brilliance of wisdom that surpasses the glow of copper, an example that was explained previously[179] and is used again here. This wisdom is born from especially cultivating the dharmas of the thirty-seven factors of perfect enlightenment.[180] Therefore, since on this ground light from the fire of wisdom radiates, it is called The Radiant.
gnyis pa (spangs pa'i yon tan bstan pa )ni/
2.2.2.1.1.4.2.2. THE TEACHING ON THE QUALITIES OF RELINQUISHMENT
rang du lta ba dang 'brel yongs su zad/ /
Everything connected with the views of “me” and “mine” is completely exhausted. (4.2d)
dbu ma la 'jug pa las sems bskyed pa bzhi pa'o/ /
This completes the fourth bodhichitta generation from The Entrance to the Middle Way.

zhes pas bstan/ sa 'dir byang phyogs kyi sgom byung gi ye shes su ma zad sa der rang du lta ba bdag dang bdag gir lta ba dang 'brel pa'i byed pa'i skyes bu gzhan du mngon zhen thams cad kyang yongs su zad par byed do/ /

On this ground, not only does wisdom arise due to cultivating the factors of enlightenment, additionally, all clinging to concepts of a creator as an external person—concepts that are connected to the views of “me” and “mine” (the self and entities connected to the self)—are completely exhausted.
dbu ma la 'jug pa las 'od 'phro zhes bya ba ste sems bskyed pa bzhi pa'i bshad pa'o// //
This completes the explanation of the fourth bodhichitta generation, The Radiant, from the Entrance to the Middle Way.
⋮ Ground Five: Difficult to Overcome
lnga pa sbyang dka' bshad pa la/
2.2.2.1.1.5. THE EXPLANATION OF DIFFICULT TO OVERCOME (Sudurjayā, Jang Kawa/sbyang dka’ ba)
sa'i ming don dang*/ yon tan bstan pa gnyis/
2.2.2.1.1.5.1. The name of the ground and its meaning 2.2.2.1.1.5.2. The teaching on the ground’s qualities
dang po ni/
2.2.2.1.1.5.1. THE NAME OF THE GROUND AND ITS MEANING
bdag nyid che de bdud rnams kun gyis kyang*/ / sbyang dka'i sa la pham par nus ma yin/ /
The great beings on the ground Difficult to Overcome Cannot be defeated by any of the māras. (5.1ab)

zhes pas bstan/ sbyang dka'i sa 'dir gnas kyi bdag nyid chen po byang sems de ni 'jig rten gyi khams na gnas pa'i lha'i bu'i bdud rnams kun gyis kyang sbyang dka'i sa la pham par nus pa ma yin na bdud kyi bka' nyan pa sogs lta ci smos/ de nyid kyi phyir sa 'di'i ming la sbyang dka' ba zhes brjod do/ /

The great bodhisattva being that abides on this ground called Difficult to Overcome cannot be defeated by any of the devaputra māras[181] who live in the worldly realms. Therefore, what need to speak of whether they obey such māras? For that reason, this ground is given the name Difficult to Overcome.
gnyis pa (yon tan bstan pa )ni/
2.2.2.1.1.5.2. THE TEACHING ON THE GROUND’S QUALITIES

bsam gtan lhag cing blo bzang bden rang bzhin/ / zhib mo rtogs la'ang shin tu mkhas pa 'thob/ /
dbu ma la 'jug pa las sems bskyed pa lnga pa'o/ /

Their concentration becomes preeminent, and their excellent intelligence Becomes very skilled at thoroughly examining the nature of the truths. (5.1cd)
This completes the fifth bodhichitta generation from the Entrance to the Middle Way.

zhes pas bstan/ sa 'dir gnas kyi sems dpa' de la ni phar phyin bcu'i nang nas bsam gtan gyi phar phyin lhag cing blo bzang por gyur pa yin te/ 'phags pa'i bden pa rnams kyi rang bzhin shes rab zhib mos rtogs par bya ba la'ang shin tu mkhas pa thob pa'i phyir/ 'dir 'phags pa'i bden pa bzhi ni/ spang bya nyon mongs pa'i rgyu 'bras dang*/ blang bya rnam byang gi rgyu 'bras kyi dbang du byas te gsungs la/ bzhi po de'ang bden gnyis su 'dus te/ sdug kun dang lam bden yang gnas skabs su 'dus byas kyi 'gyur ba dang bcas pas kun rdzob bden pas bsdus la/ 'gog bden ni de ltar ma yin pas don dam bden pas bsdus pa'i phyir/ bden bzhi bden gnyis kyi bsdu lugs cung zad dpyad pa'i gzhan ngor rnam gzhag 'di ltar yin gyi/ ches dpyad pa na gang ltos nas 'byung ba'i bya byed can gyi bden pa bzhi po'ang don dam bden par mi rung ste don 'di la rgyu 'bras la sogs par ma grub pa'i phyir/ des na bden pa gzhan bstan pa rnams kyang bden gnyis su 'dus so/ / kha cig chos dbyings yin na 'gog bden ma yin pas khyab par 'dod pa dang chos nyid 'gog bden du smra ba'ang mi 'thad ces TI kar gsungs so/ /

For bodhisattvas who abide on this ground, concentration (dhyāna, samten/bsam gtan), from among the ten perfections, is preeminent. Their intelligence becomes excellent, because they attain great skill in examining the nature of the noble truths with precise and thorough supreme knowledge. The four noble truths can be presented as two sets of cause and result: the afflictive set (what is to be relinquished), with the origin as the cause and suffering as the result, and the pure set (what is to be adopted), with the path as the cause and cessation as the result. However, these four truths can also be subsumed within the two truths of ultimate and relative. The truths of suffering, origin, and the path are relative truth, because they all entail the changes of conditioned phenomena at certain stages. The truth of cessation does not entail those changes, and therefore it is ultimate truth. The above [paragraph] on how the four truths fit into the two truths, however, only represents the presentation of slight analysis from the perspective of others. Under thorough analysis, none of the four truths, which functionally depend on the other truths for their designation as truths, are suitable as ultimate truth. They are not truly established as either causes or results. Other enumerations of truths can correlate with the two truths in a similar way.[182] In the Ṭīkā, [Karmapa Mikyö Dorje] teaches that the assertion that the dharmadhātu is necessarily not the truth of cessation is untenable, and that the assertion that dharmatā is the truth of cessation is also untenable.

The following explanation is from the perspective of the sixth bodhichitta generation. Because the bodhisattvas attained the completely pure perfection of concentration on the fifth ground, on the sixth ground, The Approach, their minds abide in equipoise. Through having focused on the truth of the path on the fifth ground, they closely approach the qualities of perfect buddhahood, the ten powers and so on. Therefore, this ground is also called The Manifest. They see the profound suchness of phenomena’s dependent arising through mere conditionality. The bodhisattvas abiding on this ground, through abiding in the completely pure perfection of supreme knowledge (prajñā, sherab/shes rab), will attain the cessation that is the pacification of all elaborations and characteristics. This was not the case before, because supreme knowledge was not preeminent.
