gang phyir de yi rang bzhin de/ / yin phyir gzugs ni gzugs kyis stong*/ / sgra dang dri ro reg bya dang*/ / chos rnams nyid kyang de bzhin no/ /
gzugs sogs rang bzhin med pa nyid/ / phyi rol stong pa nyid du 'dod/ /

Because its nature is emptiness, Form is empty of form. Sound, smell, taste, tangible objects, And mental objects are the same way. (6.183)
The lack of inherent nature of form and so on Is asserted to be the emptiness of the outer. (6.184ab)

ces pas bstan/ de la phyi stong pa nyid gang zhe na/ gzugs la sogs pa'o de la ther zug tu gnas pa ma yin pa dang 'jig pa ma yin pa nyid kyi phyir/ gzugs ni gzugs kyi stong ste de'i rang bzhin de yin pa'i phyir zhes sogs kyi don ni phyi'i skye mched drug go /de dag kyang rang rang ngo bos stong ste gang gi phyir gzugs de'i rang bzhin stong pa nyid de yin pa'i phyir/ gzugs ni gzugs kyis rang gi ngo bos stong la/ de bzhin du sgra dang dri ro reg bya dang chos rnams nyid kyang rang rang ngo bos stong pa de bzhin no/ / des na gzugs sogs phyi'i skye mched drug gi rang bzhin med pa nyid ni phyi rol stong pa nyid du 'dod do/ /

If you ask, “What is the emptiness of the outer,” this refers to form and so on. As to that, since it does not stay together and does not cease, form is empty of form, because its nature is emptiness.[*1] The meaning of that quotation is as follows. The six outer sense-sources are also empty of their own entities. Since the nature of form is emptiness, form is empty of the entity of form. Sound, smell, taste, tangible objects, and mental objects are also, in the same way, empty of their own entities. The lack of inherent nature itself of form and so on, the six outer sources, is asserted to be the emptiness of the outer.
gsum pa (phyi nang )ni/
2.2.2.1.1.6.2.3.2.2.2.1.3. THE EXTENSIVE EXPLANATION OF THE EMPTINESS OF THE OUTER AND INNER
gnyis char rang bzhin med nyid ni/ / phyi nang stong pa nyid yin no/ /
The lack of inherent nature of both outer and inner Is the emptiness of the outer and inner. (6.184cd)

zhes pas bstan/ phyi nang gi skye mched gnyis char rang ngos stong pa'i rang bzhin med pa nyid ni phyi nang stong pa nyid yin no/ / phyi nang ni dbus mtha' sogs las khog pa dang 'phags seng dbang rten la 'dod kyang 'dir bshad pa ni mdo'i dgongs pa'o/ /

The lack of inherent nature, or emptiness of own-entity, of both the outer and the inner sources is the emptiness of the outer and inner. Distinguishing the Middle from the Extremes asserts “outer and inner” as what is inside the body and what is outside the body, respectively. The tradition of the master Haribhadra[537] asserts “outer and inner” as the faculties and their supports. The explanation found here, however, follows the sūtras.
bzhi pa (stong pa nyid )ni/
2.2.2.1.1.6.2.3.2.2.2.1.4. THE EXTENSIVE EXPLANATION OF THE EMPTINESS OF EMPTINESS

chos rnams rang bzhin med pa nyid/ / mkhas pas stong pa nyid ces bsnyad/ / stong nyid de yang stong nyid kyi/ / ngo bos stong par 'dod pa yin/ /
stong nyid ces bya'i stong nyid gang*/ / stong nyid stong nyid du 'dod de/ / stong nyid dngos po'i blo can gyi/ / 'dzin pa zlog phyir gsungs pa yin/ /

The wise explain the lack of phenomena’s inherent existence To be “emptiness.” This emptiness is also asserted to be empty Of the entity of emptiness. (6.185)
The emptiness of what is called “emptiness” Is asserted to be the emptiness of emptiness. It was taught in order to reverse the fixation Of those who think of emptiness as a thing. (6.186)

zhes pas bstan/ stong pa nyid stong pa nyid gang zhe na/ chos rnams kyi stong pa nyid gang yin pa'i stong pa nyid des stong pa 'di ni stong pa nyid stong pa nyid ces bya'o zhes sogs kyi don gyi stong nyid 'di ni rgyud sde dang 'phags seng dang dbus mtha' sogs kyi chos thams cad las bshad kyang*/ 'di slob dpon gyis mdo ji lta bar 'dus byas 'dus ma byas sogs kyi chos rnams rang rang ngo bos stong pa'i rang bzhin med pa nyid la mkhas pas stong pa nyid ces bsnyad de/ sems 'grel las/ chos rnams thams cad skye med pa/ / stong nyid yin par rab tu bshad/ / ces gsungs pa'i phyir/ stong nyid de yang stong nyid kyi rang gi ngo bos stong par 'dod pa yin te/ chos can nam dgag gzhi mi stong pa'i chos cung zad cig yod na de'i steng du dgag bya 'ga' zhig bkag pa'i stong nyid kyang yod par 'gyur na/ sngar bshad kyi rigs pas mi stong pa'i chos cung zad kyang med na stong nyid kyang gzhi grub dang yod par mi 'thad pa'i phyir/ de'i phyir stong pa nyid ces bya ba rang rang gi ngo bos stong pa'i stong nyid gang yin pa de ni stong pa nyid stong pa nyid du 'dod de/ de las gzhan du kha cig stong nyid la'ang dngos po bden pa'am bden par med pa'i don byed pa can gyi dngos po dngos med du gzhi grub par rtog pa'i blo can rnams kyi 'dzin pa zlog pa'i phyir du gsungs pa yin te/ 'jig rten 'das bstod las/
kun rtog thams cad gzhom pa'i phyir/ / stong nyid bdud rtsi bstan par mdzad/ / gang la'ang de la 'dzin yod pa/ / de ni khyod kyis smad par mdzad/ /
zhes dang*/ 'od srungs kyis zhus pa las/
'od srungs gang dag stong pa nyid du dmigs pas stong pa nyid la rtog pa de dag ni ngas gsung rab 'di las rab tu nyams zhes bshad do/ /'od srung gang zag tu lta ba ri rab tsam du gnas pa ni bla'i/ mngon pa'i nga rgyal can stong pa nyid du lta ba ni de ltar ma yin no/ /de ci'i phyir zhe na/ 'od srung lta bar gyur pa thams cad las 'byung ba ni stong pa nyid yin na/ 'od srung gang dag stong pa nyid kho nar lta ba de ni gsor mi rung ngo zhes ngas bshad do/ /'od srung 'di lta ste/ dper na mi nad pa zhig yod pa la sman btang nas sman des de'i nad thams cad bskyod de/ sman lto na gnas pa de nyid mi 'byung na 'od srung de ji snyam du sems/ mi de nad las thar bar 'gyur ram/ gsol pa/ bcom ldan 'das de ni mi 'gyur lags te/ gang sman des nad thams cad las bskyod nas sman ltor mchis pa nyid ma byung na/ mi de'i bro nad shin tu tshabs cher 'gyur lags so/ /bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa/ 'od srung de bzhin du lta bar gyur pa thams cad las 'byung ba ni stong pa nyid kho na yin na/ 'od srung gang stong pa nyid kho na la lta ba de ni gsor mi rung ngo zhes ngas bshad do/ /
zhes gsungs shing*/ rgyan stug po bkod pa las kyang*/
ri rab ri bo tsam gyur pa'i/ / bdag tu lta bas mi gnod kyi/ / stong nyid lta bas gnod pa ni/ / nga rgyal mi bden brtags pas so/ / rnal 'byor spyod pa stong pa nyid/ / gnas min pa la sbyor mi bya/ / gal te gnas min sbyar gyur na/ / bdud rtsi dug tu 'thung ba yin/ / lta (342ba)ba ji snyed gang yang rung*/ / lus can rnams la yod pa yi/ / lta ba'i rnam pa spang ba'i phyir/ / stong pa nyid kyi tshul bstan te/ / stong pa nyid kyi lta thos kyang*/ / la la'i lta ba ma zhig na/ / gsor mi rung ba'i lta ba can/ / sman pas btang ba'i nad pa bzhin/ /
zhes gsungs pas stong nyid la bden par zhen pa jo dge rnams kyi 'dod pa ltar gyi gzhan stong khas len pa rnams ni sman pas bor ba'i nad pa bzhin du sgrib gnyis kyi nad ma lus pa sel bar mdzad pa'i sman pa chen po rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas kyi dam chos kyi bdud rtsis gsor mi rung ba'i lta ba can du bshad pa'i phyir/

If you ask, “What is the emptiness of emptiness,” that which is empty of the emptiness of all phenomena is the emptiness of emptiness. The topic of that quotation, the emptiness of emptiness, is taught by all of the dharma teachings of the tantras, by the tradition of Haribhadra, by the tradition associated with Distinguishing the Middle from the Extremes, and so on. However, here the master Chandrakīrti teaches in precise accordance with sūtra. The wise explain that conditioned phenomena, unconditioned phenomena, and so on lack an inherent nature or entity of their own. That lack of inherent nature, moreover, is “emptiness.” Nāgārjuna’s Commentary on Bodhichitta (Bodhichittavivaraṇa, Changchub Sem kyi Drelpa/byang chub sems kyi ’grel pa) says: The nonarising of phenomena Is excellently explained to be emptiness. This emptiness is also asserted to be empty of its own entity of emptiness. If apparent phenomena even slightly existed as bases of refutation that are not empty, emptiness as a means of refutation would also exist. However, due to the reasonings explained above, there is not even the slightest phenomenon that is not empty. It is untenable for emptiness, therefore, to be an existent or an established base. Thus the emptiness of emptiness’s own entity is asserted to be the emptiness of emptiness. Apart from that, there are some scholars who think that emptiness is established as a basis that is either a thing or a nonthing. They say that this established base performs a function, in either a real or an unreal way. However, the emptiness of emptiness was taught in order to reverse the fixation of people who think in such ways. Nāgārjuna’s Praise of the Supramundane says:
To vanquish all conceptual imagination, You taught the nectar of emptiness And denounced fixation upon it.
And, from the Sūtra Requested by Kāshyapa:[538]
Kāshyapa, concerning those who conceptually fixate on emptiness due to their observation of emptiness: I say that they have fallen far from my teachings. Kāshyapa, it is permissible to dwell in the view of the person, which is similar in stature to Mount Meru. But that is not the case regarding those who, possessing flagrant pride, espouse the view of emptiness. Why? Kāshyapa, since emptiness is what uproots all views, I teach that espousing the view of only emptiness cannot be cured. For example, Kāshyapa, if a sick person is administered medicine, and that medicine exacerbates her illnesses, Kāshyapa, what do you think? If that medicine does not leave her stomach, will she gain freedom from what ails her? Kāshyapa responded: O Blessed One, no she will not. If the medicine that exacerbates her illnesses does not leave her stomach, her illnesses will become all the more severe. The Blessed One spoke: Kāshyapa, in the same way, emptiness is what uproots all views. Kāshyapa, I teach that one who espouses a view of only emptiness will be incurable.
And, from the Thickly Arrayed Ornaments (Ghanavyūha, Gyen Tukpo Köpa/rgyan stug po bkod pa): [539]
One will not be harmed by the view of the self, Which is merely the equivalent of Mount Meru. Yet one will be harmed by the view of emptiness If one espouses pride and false imagination. Yogis and yoginīs who practice emptiness Should not use it in an inappropriate way. If they use it in an inappropriate way, Its vital nectar will turn into poison. Whatever views there are, Whatever views embodied beings have, Emptiness was taught To help beings relinquish those views. Some people may hear the view of emptiness And then fail to dismantle emptiness itself as a view. Their views will then be incurable, Like a patient forsaken by the doctor.
Those quotations speak to the approaches of those such as the Jonangpas and the Gendenpas (dge ldan pa),[540] who cling to emptiness as being real and assert extrinsic emptiness as their view. These types of scholars are explained to be like patients forsaken by their doctors, for they espouse views that cannot be cured by the nectar of genuine dharma taught by the great doctor, the perfect Buddha, who endeavors to clear away all illnesses of the two obscurations.
lnga pa (chen po )la/
2.2.2.1.1.6.2.3.2.2.2.1.5. THE EXTENSIVE EXPLANATION OF THE EMPTINESS OF THE GREAT
rten chen po can dang*/ stong tshul dang dgos pa bshad pa gnyis kyi/

2.2.2.1.1.6.2.3.2.2.2.1.5.1. The explanation of the greatness that is the support or subject 2.2.2.1.1.6.2.3.2.2.2.1.5.2. The explanations of the way in which it is empty and of the purpose of this category
dang po ni/
2.2.2.1.1.6.2.3.2.2.2.1.5.1. THE EXPLANATION OF THE GREATNESS THAT IS THE SUPPORT OR SUBJECT
sems can snod kyi 'jig rten ni/ / ma lus khyab byed nyid phyir dang*/ / tshad med dpe yis mu mtha' ni/ / med phyir phyogs rnams chen po nyid/ /
Since they pervade without exception The worlds of sentient beings’ environments, And since the example of the limitless ones shows their infinitude, The directions are “great.” (6.187)

ces pas bstan/ chen po stong pa nyid gang zhe na/ shar phyogs ni shar phyogs kyis stong ngo/ / zhes sogs kyis don chen po ni dbus mtha' la sogs pa gzhan du snod kyi 'jig rten la bshad kyang*/ 'dir yum gyi mdo bzhin du phyogs bcu ste phyogs las logs su snod bcud kyi 'jig rten med pas sems can te 'gro ba dang snod kyi 'jig rten ni ma lus par khyab par byed pa nyid kyi phyir dang*/ phyogs bcu po re rer yang byams sogs tshad med pa bsgom na phyogs yongs su bcad nas bsgoms pas tshad med pa'i dpe yis gnas pas mu mtha' ni med pa'i phyir yang phyogs bcu po rnams chen po nyid do/ /

What is the emptiness of the great? The eastern direction is empty of the eastern direction. Other texts, such as Distinguishing the Middle from the Extremes, teach that the meaning of that quotation about the emptiness of the great refers to the environment of the world. Here, however, Chandrakīrti teaches in accordance with the Mother sūtras. Beyond the ten directions—all of space—there are no worlds consisting of environments and inhabitants. Sentient beings and all environments and worlds are pervaded by these ten directions. Furthermore, these directions are completely included within the meditations of the limitless ones—loving-kindness and so on. Meditating on the four limitless ones means to be completely inclusive of all of space in one’s meditation. Thus the example of limitlessness embodied in those practices shows the infinitude of the directions. Therefore, the ten directions are indeed “great.”
gnyis pa (stong tshul dang dgos pa bshad pa )ni/
2.2.2.1.1.6.2.3.2.2.2.1.5.2. THE EXPLANATIONS OF THE WAY IN WHICH IT IS EMPTY AND OF THE PURPOSE OF THIS CATEGORY
'di dag bcu char phyogs rnams kyi/ / stong pa nyid ni gang yin de/ / chen po stong pa nyid yin te/ / chen por 'dzin pa bzlog phyir gsungs/ /
The ten directions’ Emptiness of themselves Is the emptiness of the great. It was taught in order to reverse fixation on greatness. (6.188)

zhes pas bstan/ phyogs 'di dag bcu char yang phyogs rnams kyi rang gi ngo bos stong pa nyid ni gang yin pa de ni chen po stong pa nyid yin te/ bye brag pa sogs phyogs rnams tshad med par thams cad la khyab pa'i rdzas so snyam du chen por 'dzin pa dag gi 'dzin pa bzlog pa'i phyir du gsungs pa'i phyir/

These ten directions are empty of the directions’ own entity. This emptiness is the emptiness of the great. It was taught in order to reverse the fixation on greatness that is held by people such as the Vaisheṣhikas, who think, “The directions are a substantial entity that pervades in a limitless way all of the particulars and so on of phenomena.”
drug pa (don dam pa )ni/
2.2.2.1.1.6.2.3.2.2.2.1.6. THE EXTENSIVE EXPLANATION OF THE EMPTINESS OF THE ULTIMATE

de ni dgos pa mchog yin pas/ / don dam mya ngan 'das pa yin/ / de ni de yis stong nyid gang*/ / de ni don dam stong nyid de/ /
myang 'das dngos po'i blo can gyi/ / 'dzin pa bzlog par bya ba'i phyir/ / don dam mkhyen pas don dam pa/ / stong pa nyid ni bstan par mdzad/ /

Since it is the supreme objective, Nirvāṇa is the ultimate. Its emptiness of itself Is the emptiness of the ultimate. (6.189)
In order to reverse the fixation Of those who think nirvāṇa is a thing, The Knower of the Ultimate Taught the emptiness of the ultimate. (6.190)

ces pas bstan/ de la don dam pa stong pa nyid gang zhe na/ don dam pa zhes pa ni mya ngan las 'das pa ste ther zug tu gnas pa ma yin pa dang 'jig pa ma yin pa nyid kyi phyir/ mya ngan las 'das pa ni mya ngan las 'das pas stong ngo zhes sogs kyi don la dbus mtha' sogs 'chad tshul du ma yod kyang 'dir ni mdo bzhin du mya ngan las 'das pa ste/ myang 'das de ni skyes bu'i dgos pa thams cad kyi mchog yin pas par ma ar+tha zhes pa par ma ni dam pa'am mchog la 'jug gi ar+tha ni don la 'jug pas myang 'das te don dam mya ngan las 'das pa yin zhing de ni myang 'das de yi stong nyid gang yin pa de ni don dam pa stong pa nyid de/ dngos po dang dngos med gnyis ka yin min gyi mu bzhi dang bral ba'i phyir/ bye smra sogs ldan rdzas ji snyed kyi bral rdzas de snyed du grub par 'dod pa dang*/ rnal 'byor spyod pa ba myang 'das 'gog bden grub pa'i dngos por mngon par zhen pa'i blo can rnams kyi lta ba ngan pa'i 'dzin pa zlog par bya ba'i phyir don dam mkhyen pa'i sangs rgyas kyis don dam pa stong pa nyid ni bstan par mdzad do/ /

What is the emptiness of the ultimate? That which is called the ultimate is nirvāṇa. Distinguishing the Middle from the Extremes and other texts explain this emptiness to mean that since nirvāṇa is unchanging and does not cease, it is empty of nirvāṇa. There are many such ways of explanation, but here Chandrakīrti teaches in accordance with the Perfection of Supreme Knowledge sūtras. Nirvāṇa is the supreme objective of all beings. Therefore, it is the ultimate (döndam/don dam). As to that, “ultimate” renders the Sanskrit paramārtha, of which parama means “genuine” (dam) or “supreme,” and artha means “objective” or “meaning” (don). Thus, nirvāṇa is the ultimate—the most supreme objective. The emptiness of that nirvāṇa of nirvāṇa is the emptiness of the ultimate. Nirvāṇa is empty of itself because it is free from the four possibilities of being a thing, a nonthing, both, or neither. The Particularists assert that instances of cessation through analysis are substantial entities that are equal in number to the instances of separation from the impure mental events.[541] The Practitioners of Yogic Conduct, on the other hand, assert that nirvāṇa is a thing that is established as the truth of cessation. In order to reverse such fixation and bad views of those who think of and cling to nirvāṇa as being a real thing, the Buddha, the Knower of the Ultimate, taught the emptiness of the ultimate.
bdun pa ('dus byas )ni/
2.2.2.1.1.6.2.3.2.2.2.1.7. THE EXTENSIVE EXPLANATION OF THE EMPTINESS OF THE CONDITIONED
rkyen las byung phyir khams gsum po/ / 'dus byas yin par nges par bsnyad/ / de ni de yis stong nyid gang*/ / de ni 'dus byas stong nyid gsungs/ /

Because they arise from conditions, the three realms Are definitively described as being conditioned. The three realms’ emptiness of themselves Is taught to be the emptiness of the conditioned. (6.191)

zhes pas bstan/ 'dus byas stong pa nyid gang zhe na/ 'dus byas zhes bya ba ni khams gsum mo/ / de la 'dod pa'i khams ni 'dod pa'i khams kyis stong ste/ zhes sogs kyi don 'dus byas la 'dod tshul du ma yod kyang 'dir ni mdo bzhin du rgyu dang rkyen las byung ba'i phyir khams gsum po rnams 'dus byas yin par nges par mdo las bsnyad cing khams gsum po de ni de yi rang gi ngo bos stong pa nyid gang yin pa de ni 'dus byas stong pa nyid du gsungs so/ /

What is the emptiness of the conditioned? “Conditioned” refers to the three realms. As to that, the desire realm is empty of the desire realm. The meaning of that quotation is asserted in various ways, but here Chandrakīrti teaches in accordance with the Perfection of Supreme Knowledge sūtras. Since they arise from causes and conditions, the three realms are definitively described in the sūtras as being conditioned. The three realms’ emptiness of their own entity is taught to be the emptiness of the conditioned.
brgyad pa ('dus ma byas )ni/
2.2.2.1.1.6.2.3.2.2.2.1.8. THE EXTENSIVE EXPLANATION OF THE EMPTINESS OF THE UNCONDITIONED
gang la skye gnas mi rtag nyid/ / de dag med pa 'dus ma byas/ / de ni de yis stong nyid gang*/ / de ni 'dus ma byas stong nyid/ /
Phenomena free from Arising, abiding, and impermanence are unconditioned. Their emptiness of their own entity Is the emptiness of the unconditioned. (6.192)

ces pas bstan/ de la 'dus ma byas stong pa nyid gang zhe na/ 'dus ma byas zhes bya ba ni gang la skye ba med pa dang 'gag pa med pa dang 'jig pa med pa dang gnas pa las gzhan du 'gyur ba med pa'o/ / de la 'dus ma byas ni 'dus ma byas kyis stong ste/ zhes sogs kyi don 'dir ni mdo gzhan du gang la thog mar skye ba dang bar du gnas pa dang tha mar mi rtag pa nyid de 'dus byas kyi mtshan nyid gsum po de dag med pa ni 'dus ma byas yin la de ni 'dus ma byas de yis stong pa nyid gang yin pa de ni 'dus ma byas stong pa nyid do/ / 'dis kyang nam mkha' sogs 'dus ma byas la rtag 'dzin zlog pa'o/ /

What is the emptiness of the unconditioned? “Unconditioned” means to be free from arising, free from cessation, free from disintegration, and free from changing from the state of abiding into something else. The unconditioned is empty of the unconditioned. The meaning of that quotation is explained here in accordance with the sūtras. That which is free from the three defining characteristics of conditioned phenomena—arising in the beginning, abiding in the middle, and impermanence in the end—is unconditioned. Unconditioned phenomena’s emptiness of themselves is the emptiness of the unconditioned. The teaching about this emptiness reverses fixation towards unconditioned phenomena, such as space, as being permanent.
dgu pa (mtha' las 'das pa )ni/
2.2.2.1.1.6.2.3.2.2.2.1.9. THE EXTENSIVE EXPLANATION OF THE EMPTINESS OF WHAT IS BEYOND EXTREMES
gang la mtha' ni yod min pa/ / de ni mtha' las 'das par brjod/ / de de kho nas stong pa nyid/ / mtha' las 'das pa stong nyid bsnyad/ /
That which does not have an extreme Is called “beyond the extremes.” Its emptiness of precisely itself Is explained as the emptiness of what is beyond extremes. (6.193)

ces pas bstan/ de la mtha' las 'das pa stong pa nyid gang zhe na/ mtha' zhes bya ba ni rtag pa'i mtha' dang chad pa'i mtha' ste/ gang la mtha' yod pa ma yin pa de ni mtha' las 'das pa'o/ / mtha' las 'das pa ni mtha' las 'das pas stong ste/ zhes sogs kyi don mtha' las 'das pa ni 'dir ni mdo bzhin du gang la rtag chad kyi mtha' ni yod pa min pa mtha' gnyis dang bral ba dbu ma'i lam de ni mtha' las 'das par brjod do/ / mtha' las 'das pa de mtha' las 'das pa de kho nas stong pa nyid ni mtha' las 'das pa stong pa nyid du bsnyad do/ / kha cig mtha' las 'das pa'i dbu ma'i lam rtag dngos su 'dod pa'ang gzhung 'dis bkag 'dug go /

What is the emptiness of that which is beyond extremes? “Extremes” refers to the extreme of eternalism and to the extreme of nihilism. That which does not have an extreme is “beyond the extremes.” What is beyond the extremes is empty of what is beyond the extremes. The meaning of the above is explained here according to the sūtras. That which does not have an extreme of eternalism or nihilism but is rather free from these two extremes is the path of the Middle Way, which is called “beyond the extremes.” The state of what is beyond the extremes being empty of precisely itself is explained as the “emptiness of what is beyond extremes.” This section of text refutes the assertion of some that the path beyond the extremes is a permanent thing.
bcu pa (thog ma dang tha ma med pa )ni/
2.2.2.1.1.6.2.3.2.2.2.1.10. THE EXTENSIVE EXPLANATION OF THE EMPTINESS OF THE BEGINNINGLESS AND ENDLESS

thog ma dang po tha ma mtha'/ / de dag med pas 'khor ba ni/ / thog ma tha ma med par brjod/ / 'gro 'ong bral phyir rmi lam lta'i/ /
srid 'di de yis dben nyid gang*/ / de ni thog ma dang tha ma/ / med pa stong pa nyid do zhes/ / bstan bcos las ni nges par bsnyad/ /

Since it is free From a beginning at the start and an end at the finish, Saṃsāra is described as being beginningless and endless. Since it is free from coming and going, (6.194)
Cyclic existence, like an illusion, is devoid of its own entity. This is the emptiness Of the beginningless and endless. It was definitively explained in the treatises. (6.195)

ces pas bstan/ de la thog ma dang tha ma med pa stong pa nyid gang zhe na/ gang la thog ma dang tha ma mi dmigs pa de la 'ong ba dang 'gro ba med do/ / de ther zug tu gnas pa ma yin pa dang 'jig pa ma yin pa nyid kyi phyir thog ma dang tha ma dang dbus rnams ni thog ma dang tha ma dang dbus rnams kyis stong ste/ zhes sogs kyi don thog ma dang tha ma med pa ni 'khor ba ste/ thog ma ni dang po dang tha ma ni mtha' ste/ de dag med pas 'khor ba ni thog ma dang tha ma med par brjod do/ / 'dir thog mtha' dbus gsum du med pa'i don yang kun rdzob 'khrul ngor thog mtha' med pa'i don la mi bzung gi 'khor ba rang bzhin med pa skye 'jig gnas pa dang bral ba la 'jog go /thog mtha' dbus gsum bral ba la 'di nas gzhan du 'gro ba dang snga ma nas 'dir 'ong ba dang bral ba'i phyir rmi lam lta bu'i srid pa 'di de'i ngo bo yis dben pa nyid gang yin pa de ni thog ma dang tha ma med pa'i stong pa nyid do zhes 'chos skyob kyi yon tan dang ldan pa'i sher phyin gyi bstan bcos las ni nges par bsnyad do/ /

What is the emptiness of the beginningless and endless? That which has no observable beginning or end is free from coming and going. Since it does not stay together and does not cease, it is free from beginning, end, and middle. The meaning of the above quotation is as follows. That which is free from beginning and end is saṃsāra. Since saṃsāra is free from a beginning at the start and an end at the finish, it is described as being beginningless and endless. Here, the phrase “free from beginning, end, and middle” does not refer to a freedom from beginning and end from the confused perspective of the relative. Rather, it refers to saṃsāra’s inherent nature—saṃsāra is free from arising, abiding, and disintegration. Since this state of being free from beginning, end, and middle does not go somewhere else later, and since it does not come from some place it was before, cyclic existence is like an illusion. It is devoid of its own entity. This is the emptiness of the beginningless and endless. It was definitively explained in the treatises of the perfection of supreme knowledge, which possess the qualities of transformation and protection.
bcu gcig pa (dor ba med pa )ni/
2.2.2.1.1.6.2.3.2.2.2.1.11. THE EXTENSIVE EXPLANATION OF THE EMPTINESS OF WHAT IS NOT TO BE DISCARDED

dor ba zhes bya 'thor ba dang*/ / 'bor ba la ni nges par brjod/ / dor med gtong ba med pa ste/ / 'ga' yang dor med gang yin pa'o/ /
dor ba med pa de nyid kyis/ / de nyid stong pa nyid gang yin/ / de de'i phyir na dor med pa/ / stong pa nyid ces bya bar brjod/ /

“To discard” is definitively explained As “to cast away” or “to abandon.” What should not be discarded Is that of which one should never let go. (6.196)
What is not to be discarded Is empty precisely of itself. Therefore, this emptiness is called The emptiness of what is not to be discarded. (6.197)

ces pas bstan/ de la dor ba med pa stong pa nyid gang zhe na/ dor ba ni 'thor ba dang 'bor ba dang stong pa'o/ / de la dor ba med pa ni dor ba med pas stong ste/ zhes sogs kyi don dor ba med pa ni 'chad tshul du ma yod pa las 'dir dor ba zhes bya ba ni 'thor ba dang 'bor ba la ni nges par brjod cing dor med ni tha snyad du gtong ba med pa ste dor bya min zhing 'ga' yang 'bor ba med pa blang bya sbyin sogs tshogs gnyis kyi dge ba gang yin pa'o/ / dor ba med pa de nyid kyis dor ba med pa de nyid stong pa nyid gang yin pa de ni rgyu mtshan de'i phyir na dor ba med pa stong pa nyid ces bya bar brjod do/ /

What is the emptiness of what is not to be discarded? To discard is to cast away, to abandon, or to empty. What is not to be discarded is empty of what is not to be discarded. The meaning of the above is explained in many ways, but here its meaning is explained as follows. “To discard” is definitively expressed as “to cast away” or “to abandon.” That which is not to be discarded refers to that of which, conventionally, one should not let go. What should not be discarded is not an object of relinquishment and should in no way be abandoned. It is, rather, what should be adopted: the virtue of the two accumulations,[542] such as generosity. Those very things that are not to be discarded are empty of what is not to be discarded. Therefore, this emptiness is called the emptiness of what is not to be discarded.
bcu gnyis pa (rang bzhin )ni/
2.2.2.1.1.6.2.3.2.2.2.1.12. THE EXTENSIVE EXPLANATION OF THE EMPTINESS OF NATURE

'dus byas la sogs ngo bo nyid/ / gang phyir slob ma rang sangs rgyas/ / rgyal sras de bzhin gshegs rnams kyis/ / ma mdzad de'i phyir 'dus byas la/ /
sogs pa rnams kyi ngo bo nyid/ / rang bzhin nyid du bsnyad pa ste/ / de nyid kyis de stong nyid gang*/ / de ni rang bzhin stong pa nyid/ /

The essence of conditioned phenomena and so on Is not created by the students—the solitary realizers And bodhisattvas—or by the Buddha himself. Therefore the essence, emptiness, of conditioned phenomena (6.198)
And so on Is explained to be their nature. Its emptiness of itself Is the emptiness of nature. (6.199)

ces pas bstan/ de la rang bzhin stong pa nyid gang zhe na/ gang chos rnams kyi rang bzhin ma byas shing mngon par 'dus ma byas pa ste/ de ni nyan thos rnams kyis ma byas/ zhes sogs kyi don 'dus byas 'dus ma byas la sogs kyi chos rnams kyi ngo bo nyid rang bzhin gang yin pa de ni gang gi phyir slob ma nyan thos dang rang sangs rgyas dang rgyal sras byang sems dang de bzhin gshegs pa rnams kyis shes pa dang mthong bas ma mdzad de/ de dag byon rung ma byon rung chos rnams kyi rang bzhin gdod nas stong pa'i stong nyid yin pa'i phyir/ ma mdzad pa de'i phyir 'dus byas la sogs pa rnams kyi ngo bo stong pa nyid de ni rang bzhin nyid du bsnyad pa ste/ rang bzhin med pa la rang bzhin gyi ming gis btags pa'o/ / 'o na dbu ma'i gsung rab kyi brda 'dir me'i rang bzhin tsha ba sogs la'ang rang bzhin du brjod rigs par 'gyur te/ de 'phags sogs kyis ma byas pa'i phyir snyam na/ ma dpyad na der brjod pa mi 'gog mod/ 'on te tsha sogs 'phags pas ma byas kyang gzhan grags kyi rigs pas rang bzhin yin par mi rigs te/ rang bzhin bcos min dang gzhan la mi ltos pa yin pas tsha sogs ni 'phags pas ma byas kyang ma rig pa sogs kyis byas pa'i phyir/ stong nyid ni byis pa'i dus ma rtogs pa 'phags pas mngon sum gzigs pa'i phyir/ 'phags pas byas sam snyam pa'i dogs gzhi yod pas 'phags pas ma byas par bstan pas 'phags pa las gzhan pa'i rgyu rkyen gang yang ma mthong nas 'phags pas ma byas na bcos min dang ltos min yin pas rang bzhin du 'thad do/ / de lta bu'i rang bzhin de nyid kyis rang bzhin de stong pa nyid gang yin pa de ni rang bzhin stong pa nyid do/ / jo nang pas chos thams cad kyi rang bzhin don dam bden pa rtag bden rang gi ngo bo rang gis mi stong par 'dod pas chos thams cad rang bzhin gyis stong pa nyid dang rang bzhin gyis stong pa nyid kyi tshul 'dis legs par bkag pa yin la/

What is the emptiness of nature? The nature of phenomena is not created, nor was it conditioned. It was not created by the hearers… The meaning of the above is as follows. The essence or nature of conditioned and unconditioned phenomena is something that neither students of the Buddha—the hearers, solitary realizers, and heirs of the victorious ones—nor the Tathāgata himself created through knowing it or seeing it. Regardless of whether these individuals arrive or do not arrive in the world, the nature of phenomena is emptiness—phenomena are primordially empty. Since this was not created by any of these individuals, the essence, or emptiness, of conditioned phenomena and so on is explained to be their nature. This is a case of giving the name “nature” to the lack of nature. You may think, “According to this symbolism of the Middle Way scriptures, it would be logical to express the qualities of fire, heat, and so forth as a nature. For those qualities were not created by noble beings and the like.” It is true that without analysis such a nature would not be refuted. However, even though heat and so forth were not created by noble ones, it is still illogical for those qualities to be natures from the perspective of other-approved reasonings. This is so because a nature is something that is uncontrived and nondependent upon others, whereas heat and so forth, though not created by noble ones, are created by ignorance and the other [links of dependent arising]. Emptiness, on the other hand, is not realized at the time of being an ordinary being, yet it is seen directly by noble beings. For this reason it is possible for ordinary beings to be doubtful regarding whether emptiness was created by noble beings. To address such doubts, the Buddha taught that emptiness was not created by the noble ones. Since no cause or condition for emptiness apart from the noble ones’ perception can be found, and since the noble ones as well did not create emptiness, emptiness can be tenably described as a “nature” that is uncontrived and independent. Such a nature’s emptiness of itself is “the emptiness of nature.” The Jonangpas assert that the nature of all phenomena, the ultimate truth, is permanent and stable, and is not empty of its own entity. Their position is well refuted here, using the teaching that the empty nature of all phenomena is empty of its own nature.

de bzhin tsong kha pa chen pos kyang gzugs sogs kyi chos rang ngos stong pa'i rang bzhin stong pa nyid legs par bkag nas shes byar ye med pa'i chos srid na de bkag pa'i rang bzhin med pa'i stong pa nyid de de nyid kyis stong ste/ de'ang rtags kyi dgag bya shes byar med pas stong par 'dod pas kyang yum la sogs par stong pa nyid gzugs sogs kyi rang bzhin dang ngo bo yin pas rten 'brel gzhan grags su gsungs pa dang rang bzhin stong nyid stong nyid du gsungs pa gnyis ka bkag par byas pa yin te/ gzugs sogs rang rang ngo bos mi stong na chos thams cad kyi rang bzhin stong nyid du mi 'grub pa'i phyir dang*/ shes byar ye med kyi stong nyid kyi rang bzhin yang stong nyid de nyid kyis mi stong bar da dung yang rtags kyi dgag byar stong pa'i stong nyid du khyed 'dod la/ de lta na rang bzhin stong nyid kyang stong nyid du ma song bar rang bzhin dang bcas pa nyid du 'gyur ba'i phyir dang*/ de lta'i stong nyid de gzugs sogs kyi rang bzhin stong nyid stong nyid du'ang mi 'gyur ba'i phyir/ de lta na rang bzhin dang bcas par 'gyur kyang skyon med de/ don dam pa'i rang bzhin yin pa'i phyir snyam na/ bcom ldan 'das kyis chos thams cad mi stong pa dngos por lta ba'i gnyen por stong pa nyid bstan na stong pa rang rang gi ngo bos mi stong par gzhi grub pa'i rang bzhin can du yod cing der lta na ni de las dngos por lta ba ches che ba ci zhig yod de/ me gsod pa la chu dgos na chu nyid mer 'bar na chu gsod thabs 'gar yang mi rnyed pa ltar ro/ / rang bzhin myang 'das te/ mya ngan 'das pa bden gcig pu zhes pa 'di kun rdzob bden pa rang bzhin gyis te gdod nas bden par med par bden zhes kun rdzob la bden pa ye mi 'grub ces pa'i don yin gyi/ rang bzhin myang 'das de nyid de dang der bden pa'i dgongs pa thal 'gyur smra ba'i lugs mchog 'chad par skabs 'dir gtan min kyang bod la la lung des bden pa gnyis las kun rdzob bden pa ni tha snyad du'ang bden par med la don dam bden pa ni tha snyad du'ang bden par grub par brjod cing*/ khyad par zi lung pa chen pos thal 'gyur ba'i lugs la'ang don dam pa'i rang bzhin bden grub tu 'dod pa'i skabs khas len par byed pa 'di ni thal 'gyur ba la skur 'debs bla na med par 'gyur te/ des de ltar bzhed na rang bzhin stong nyid gsungs pa'i skabs 'dir de des stong pa dang mi stong pa'i lugs gnyis ma phyed par rang bzhin de nyid kyis stong pa nyid kho nar bshad snang ba'i phyir/

The great Tsongkapa refutes the nature of phenomena (such as form) that is their emptiness of their own entities. He proposes instead that if the object of refutation by reasons (which has never existed among knowable objects) were to exist, it would be refuted by the nature that he calls emptiness. However, for him that emptiness is not empty of itself—it is empty of, again, the object of refutation by reasons, which does not exist among knowable objects. His positions are refuted, however, in the Mother sūtras on the perfection of supreme knowledge. In those scriptures, the Buddha teaches how, in an interdependent and other-approved way, emptiness is the nature and essence of phenomena such as form. He also teaches how the emptiness nature of phenomena is itself emptiness. For, if form and so on were not empty of their own entities, emptiness would not be established in any way as the nature of all phenomena. You assert a nature of emptiness that is empty of something that has never existed among knowable objects. That emptiness, moreover, is not empty of itself, but it is empty yet again of the object of refutation by reasons. According to you, the empty nature of phenomena would, rather than being emptiness, have an inherent nature of its own. Your emptiness would not be the emptiness of form and so on, which is empty of emptiness. You may respond, “The nature of emptiness does have a nature of its own, but there is no fault, because that nature is an ultimate nature.” The Transcendent Conqueror taught emptiness as an antidote to views that regard any phenomenon as not being empty. If you view emptiness as something that is not empty of its own entity but instead has a nature of being an established base, what greater form of reification than that view could there be? Your approach is similar to doubting the ability of water to extinguish fire and then having the water itself blaze as fire—you will be left without any way to extinguish the water. [Let us now examine another incorrect view]: When the Buddha spoke of natural nirvāṇa, or “the nirvāṇa that is the only truth,” he described the relative truth as being “real in the sense of being primordially unreal.” The meaning of that statement is that, from the outset, the relative possesses no reality whatsoever. From the standpoint of the supreme tradition of the Consequentialists, the purpose of those statements was not to declare that natural nirvāṇa is real in certain contexts. Some scholars, however, interpret those statements as proof that the relative truth is not real even conventionally but the ultimate truth is truly existent, even conventionally. In particular, the great Zilungpa asserts that, even in the system of the Consequentialists, there are times when it is appropriate to assert the nature of the ultimate as being truly existent. There can be no greater deprecation of the Consequentialist tradition than this. For, in this context of the teachings on the emptiness of nature, there is no split approach by which sometimes the nature is considered empty of itself and sometimes not—it is taught to apply universally that the nature is empty of itself.
bcu gsum pa (chos thams cad )ni/
2.2.2.1.1.6.2.3.2.2.2.1.13. THE EXTENSIVE EXPLANATION OF THE EMPTINESS OF ALL PHENOMENA

khams bco brgyad dang reg drug dang*/ / de las byung ba'i tshor drug dang*/ / gzugs can gzugs can min de bzhin/ / 'dus byas 'dus ma byas chos rnams/ /
chos de dag ni thams cad kyi/ / de dag gis dben stong nyid gang*/ /

“All phenomena” refers to the eighteen constituents, the six types of contact, The six feelings that arise from contact, Physical phenomena, nonphysical phenomena, And conditioned and unconditioned phenomena. (6.200)
All of these phenomena are void of their own entity. This emptiness is the emptiness of all phenomena. (6.201ab)

zhes pas bstan/ de la chos thams cad stong pa nyid gang zhe na/ chos ces bya ba ni 'dus byas rnams dang 'dus ma byas rnams dang zhes sogs kyi don la 'chad tshul mang yang 'dir mdo bzhin du chos thams cad ni mig sogs nang gi khams rnams dang gzugs sogs phyi'i khams rnams dang rnam par shes pa'i khams sogs khams bco brgyad dang mig gi 'dus te reg pa nas yid kyi 'dus te reg pa'i bar reg pa drug dang reg pa de dag las byung ba'i tshor ba drug dang*/ gzugs can dang gzugs can min pa dang de bzhin du 'dus byas 'dus ma byas kyi chos thams cad ces bsnyad do/ / chos de dag rnams ni chos thams cad kyi rang gi ngo bo de dag gis dben zhing stong nyid gang yin pa de ni chos thams cad stong pa nyid do/ / khams bco brgyad du reg drug dang tshor drug 'dus te reg drug dang tshor drug smos pa ni de dag 'dod chags kyi dngos kyi rgyu yin pas gtso bor bstan to/ / bco brgyad du gzugs can gzugs can min pa dang 'dus byas dang 'dus ma byas kyang de dag tu 'dus kyang de dag logs su smos pa ni phye na bco brgyad yin kyang bsdu na de dag tu 'du bas so/ /

What is the emptiness of all phenomena? “Phenomena” include the conditioned, the unconditioned… The meaning of the above quotation is explained in many different ways, but here is explained in accordance with the sūtras. “All phenomena” refers to the eighteen constituents: the inner constituents (the eye and so on), the outer constituents (form and so on), and the consciousness constituents; the six types of contact: contact of the eye that meets with its objects through contact of the mind that meets with its objects; the six feelings that arise from those forms of contact; physical phenomena; nonphysical phenomena; conditioned phenomena; and unconditioned phenomena. All phenomena are void of their own entity. This emptiness is the emptiness of all phenomena. Although the six types of contact and the six feelings are included within the eighteen constituents, the reason for teaching the six types of contact and the six feelings as foremost is because they are the direct causes of desire. Also included in the eighteen constituents are physical phenomena and nonphysical phenomena, as well as conditioned phenomena and unconditioned phenomena. The reason for teaching these separately is because, in an elaborate classification scheme, one may speak of eighteen constituents, but if those classifications are condensed, they may be condensed into either of these two latter pairings.
bcu bzhi pa (rang gi mtshan nyid )la/

ngo bo mdor bstan/ chos can rgyas par bshad/ rten bsdu zhing stong tshul gyi don bsdu ba gsum gyi/

2.2.2.1.1.6.2.3.2.2.2.1.14.1. THE BRIEF TEACHING OF THE ESSENCE
gzugs rung la sogs dngos med gang*/ / de ni rang mtshan stong pa nyid/ /
“Suitable as form” and so on are not things. This is the emptiness of defining characteristics. (6.201cd)

ces pas bstan/ de la rang gi mtshan nyid stong pa nyid gang zhe na/ gzugs ni 'jig pa'i mtshan nyid/ tshor ba ni myong ba'i mtshan nyid/ 'du shes ni 'dzin pa'i mtshan nyid/ 'du byed ni mngon par 'du byed pa'i mtshan nyid/ rnam par shes pa ni rnam par rig pa'i mtshan nyid do/ / ther zug tu gnas pa ma yin pa dang 'jig pa med pa'i phyir 'dus byas kyi chos kyi mtshan nyid gang yin pa dang 'dus ma byas kyi chos rnams kyi mtshan nyid gang yin pa'i chos rnams kyi rang gi mtshan nyid ni rang gi mtshan nyid kyis stong ngo zhes sogs kyi don gzugs kyi mtshan nyid gzugs su rung ba la sogs pa nas rnam mkhyen gyi mtshan nyid mngon sum du byed pa'i bar de dag dngos po med pa gang yin pa de ni rang gi mtshan nyid stong pa nyid do/ /

What is the emptiness of defining characteristics?[543] The defining characteristic of form is to be suitable as form. The defining characteristic of feeling is to experience. The defining characteristic of discrimination is to apprehend. The defining characteristic of formation is to form. The defining characteristic of consciousness is to be aware. Because they do not stay together and do not cease, the defining characteristics of phenomena—of conditioned phenomena and of unconditioned phenomena—are empty of their own defining characteristics. The meaning of the above quotation is as follows. The defining characteristic of form, “suitable as form,” through the defining characteristic of omniscience, “to actualize” (ngön du jepa/mngon du byed pa), are not real things. This is the emptiness of defining characteristics.

2.2.2.1.1.6.2.3.2.2.2.1.14.2.1.1. THE DEFINING CHARACTERISTICS OF THE AGGREGATES AND CONSTITUENTS

gzugs ni gzugs rung mtshan nyid can/ / tshor ba myong ba'i bdag nyid can/ / 'du shes mtshan mar 'dzin pa ste/ / 'du byed mngon par 'du byed pa'o/ /
yul la so sor rnam rig pa/ / rnam shes rang gi mtshan nyid do/ / phung po sdug bsngal rang mtshan nyid/ / khams kyi bdag nyid sbrul gdug 'dod/ /

Form bears the defining characteristic of “suitable as form.” Feeling is of the character of “experience.” Discrimination apprehends characteristics; Formation refers to “forming.” (6.202)
Individually cognizing objects Is the defining characteristic of consciousness. The aggregates’ defining characteristic is suffering. The character of the constituents is that of a poisonous snake. (6.203)

ces pas bstan/ gzugs la sogs pa rnams kyi mtshan nyid ci zhe na/ de dag rgyas par bstan pa'i phyir gzugs ni gzugs can nang phan tshun phrad nas 'gyur ba bskyed du rung ba'i phyir gzugs su rung ba'i mtshan nyid can no/ / tshor ba ni dge sdig gi rnam smin sim gdung sogs myong ba'i mtshan nyid can no/ / 'du shes ni chos rnams kyi thun mong ma yin pa'i mtshan mar 'dzin pa ste/ 'du byed ni sems yul la mngon par 'du byed cing g.yo bar byed pa'o/ / gzugs sogs yul rnams la so sor rnam par rig pa ni rnam shes rang gi mtshan nyid do/ / nyer len gyi phung po rnams ni sdug bsngal gsum gang rung gi rang gi mtshan nyid do/ / khams rnams kyi bdag nyid 'dzin par chos mthun pa'i sgo nas sbrul gdug pa'i mtshan nyid can du 'dod do/ /

What are the defining characteristics of form and so on? The following explanation is given in order to elaborate extensively on those characteristics. The definition of form is “that which is suitable as form,” because when physical phenomena contact each other, they are suitable to produce a transformation. The definition of feeling is “that which experiences” the results of virtue and misdeeds—satiation and agony, and so on. Discrimination is defined as that which apprehends the uncommon characteristics of phenomena. Formation is defined as the mind that forms things and moves in relation to objects. The definition of consciousness is that which individually cognizes objects such as form. The defining characteristic of the appropriated aggregates is any one of the three kinds of suffering.[544] The definition of the constituents is identified by using the example of a similar phenomenon: poisonous snakes.[545]
gnyis pa (skye mched )ni/
2.2.2.1.1.6.2.3.2.2.2.1.14.2.1.2. THE DEFINING CHARACTERISTICS OF THE SOURCES
skye mched rnams ni sangs rgyas kyis/ / skye ba'i sgor gyur nyid du gsungs/ /
The Buddha taught that the sources Are the doors for the arising of suffering. (6.204ab)
zhes pas bstan/ skye mched bcu gnyis po rnams ni sangs rgyas kyis sdug bsngal 'byung zhing skye ba'i sgor gyur pa nyid du gsungs so/ /
The Buddha taught that the twelve sources are the doors for the arising or origination of suffering.
gsum pa (rten 'brel gyi rang mtshan )ni/
2.2.2.1.1.6.2.3.2.2.2.1.14.2.1.3. THE DEFINING CHARACTERISTICS OF INTERDEPENDENCE
rten cing 'brel bar 'byung ba gang*/ / de ni 'du 'phrod mtshan nyid do/ /

zhes pas bstan/ rten cing 'brel bar 'byung ba gang de ni rgyu rkyen 'dus shing tshogs pa las byung ba'i phyir 'du 'phrod kyi mtshan nyid do/ /
Since dependent arising takes place due to the coming together and assembling of causes and conditions, its defining characteristics are assembly and contact.

2.2.2.1.1.6.2.3.2.2.2.1.14.2.2.1.1. THE DEFINING CHARACTERISTICS OF THE PERFECTIONS, THE CONCENTRATIONS, AND SO ON

gtong ba sbyin pa'i pha rol phyin/ / tshul khrims gdung med mtshan nyid bzod/ / khro med mtshan nyid brtson 'grus kyi/ / kha na ma tho med nyid do/ /
bsam gtan sdud pa'i mtshan nyid can/ / shes rab chags med mtshan nyid de/ / pha rol phyin pa drug rnams kyi/ / mtshan nyid 'di dag yin par brjod/ / bsam gtan rnams dang tshad med dang*/ / de bzhin gzhan gang gzugs med pa/ / de dag yang dag mkhyen pa yis/ / mi 'khrugs mtshan nyid can du gsungs/ /

zhes pas bstan/ phar phyin drug las rang gi lus longs spyod 'bras bu dang bcas te sems can la gtong ba sbyin pa'i pha rol tu phyin pa dang*/ tshul khrims ni gzhan la gnod 'tshe spong zhing phan 'dogs pas nyon mongs pas gdung ba med pa'i mtshan nyid can no/ / bzod pa ni gnod byed la khro ba med pa'i mtshan nyid can dang*/ brtson 'grus kyi mtshan nyid ni dge ba yongs su 'dzin pa'i bdag nyid can yin pas kha na ma tho ba med pa nyid do/ / bsam gtan ni dge ba'i chos thams cad sdud pa'i mtshan nyid can no/ / shes rab ni mya ngan las 'das par bgrod pa'i phyir 'gar yang chags pa med pa'i mtshan nyid can nyid de/ de ni pha rol phyin pa drug po rnams kyi rang gi mtshan nyid ni 'di dag yin par brjod do/ / bsam gtan bzhi pa rnams dang*/ tshad med pa bzhi dang*/ de bzhin gzhan gang gzugs med pa bzhi po de dag ni yang dag mkhyen pa sangs rgyas rgyal ba yis mi 'khrugs pa khro ba med pa'i mtshan nyid can du gsungs te/ de dag ni 'dod pa la 'dod chags spangs shing khong khro spongs pas thob pa'i phyir/

From among the six perfections, to give to sentient beings one’s body, enjoyments, and positive results is the perfection of generosity. Since through discipline one abandons harming others and instead of harming them helps them, the defining characteristic of discipline is to be without the torment of the mental afflictions. The definition of patience is to be free from anger towards those who do harm. The definition of exertion is to be free from nonvirtue, since exertion is of the nature of fully taking hold of virtue. The definition of concentration is to draw together all positive qualities. The definition of supreme knowledge is to be free from attachment, since through supreme knowledge one travels to the state of nirvāṇa. These are stated to be the defining characteristics of these six perfections. The victorious Perfect Knower, the Buddha, taught that the four concentrations,[546] the four limitless ones,[547] and the four formless states[548] bear the definition “free of disturbance,” or free of anger, because all of them are attained through the relinquishment of attachment and aversion in relation to the desirable.
gnyis pa (byang phyogs )ni/
2.2.2.1.1.6.2.3.2.2.2.1.14.2.2.1.2. THE DEFINING CHARACTERISTICS OF THE FACTORS OF ENLIGHTENMENT
byang chub phyogs ni sum cu bdun/ / nges par 'byung byed rang mtshan nyid/ /
The thirty-seven factors of enlightenment Bear the defining characteristic of “that which brings deliverance.” (6.208ab)
ces pas bstan/ byang chub kyi phyogs kyi chos ni sum cu rtsa bdun po rnams 'khor ba las 'da' ba'i rgyu yin pa'i phyir thar par nges par 'byung bar byed nus pa'i rang gi mtshan nyid can no/ /

Because they are the cause by which one transcends saṃsāra, the thirty-seven factors of enlightenment[549] bear the defining characteristic of “that which is able to bring deliverance into liberation.”
gsum pa (rnam thar sgo gsum )ni/
2.2.2.1.1.6.2.3.2.2.2.1.14.2.2.1.3. THE DEFINING CHARACTERISTICS OF THE THREE GATES OF LIBERATION

stong pa nyid kyi mtshan nyid ni/ / dmigs pa med pas rnam dben nyid/ /
mtshan ma med pa zhi nyid de/ / gsum pa'i mtshan nyid sdug bsngal dang*/ / gti mug med/

The defining characteristic of emptiness is voidness, Since in emptiness there is no observation of things. (6.208cd)
The absence of characteristics is peace, And the definition of the third gate Is to be free from suffering and ignorance. (6.209abc)

ces pas bstan/ rnam par thar pa'i sgo stong pa nyid kyi mtshan nyid ni dngos po dmigs pa med pas rnam par rtog pa'i dri mas nye bar ma sbags pa'i phyir rnam par dben pa'i mtshan nyid can no/ / rnam par thar pa'i sgo mtshan ma med pa'i mtshan nyid ni mtshan ma ma dmigs pa'i sgo nas zhi ba'i mtshan nyid de/ rnam par thar pa'i sgo gsum pa smon pa med pa'i mtshan nyid ni sdug bsngal dang gti mug med pa'i mtshan nyid can te/ 'du byed sdug bsngal gyi bdag nyid can rnams la rjes su lta zhing shes rab kyis 'du byed kyi rang bzhin la lta ba na smon par mi byed pa'i phyir/

The three gates of liberation[550] will now be defined. The defining characteristic of emptiness is voidness. For, since in emptiness there is no observation of things, it is not corrupted by the stains of thoughts. The absence of characteristics bears the defining characteristic of being the peace that is the nonobservation of characteristics. Wishlessness, the third of the three gates of liberation, bears the defining characteristic of being free from suffering and ignorance. It is free of those qualities because, when its supreme knowledge examines the nature of the all-pervasive suffering of formations, it does not engender wishfulness in relation to that suffering.
bzhi pa (rnam thar brgyad kyi mtshan nyid bshad pa )ni/
2.2.2.1.1.6.2.3.2.2.2.1.14.2.2.1.4. THE DEFINING CHARACTERISTICS OF THE EIGHT FORMS OF LIBERATION
rnam thar rnams kyi/ / mtshan nyid rnam par grol byed pa'o/ /
The eight forms of liberation Bear the defining characteristic of causing liberation. (6.209cd)

zhes pas bstan/ rnam thar brgyad po rnams kyi mtshan nyid ni snyoms 'jug gi sgrib pa las grol bar byed pa'i phyir rnam par grol bar byed pa'i mtshan nyid can yin pa'o/ / brgyad ni/ gzugs can gzugs la lta ba ni rnam thar dang po'o/ / nang gzugs med par 'du shes pas phyi rol gyi gzugs rnams la lta ba ni gnyis pa'o/ / sdug pa'i rnam par thar pa bsam gtan bzhi pa'i bdag nyid can ni gsum pa'o/ / gzugs med kyi rnam thar bzhi dang 'du shes dang tshor ba 'gog pa'i rnam thar ro/ / dang po ni/ sprul pa'i sgrib pa las grol bar bya ba'i phyir bsam gtan gyi dngos gzhi la brten nas rnal 'byor pa bdag la gzugs can gyi 'du shes nye bar bzhag ste/ phyi rol gyi gzugs rnams la sdug mi sdug che chung sna tshogs par mos par byed pa'i zhi lhag gi ting nge 'dzin dang shes rab mtshungs ldan dang bcas pa'o/ / gnyis pa ni/ gzhan sngar dang 'dra shing rnal 'byor pa rang nyid la gzugs can gyi 'du shes nye bar bshig pa ni khyad par ro/ / gsum pa ni gzugs sdug mi sdug sprul pa la 'dod pa dang mi 'dod pa'i sgrib pa las grol ba'i phyir bsam gtan bzhi pa la brten nas rnal 'byor pa rang la gzugs kyi 'du shes bshig nas gzugs sdug mi sdug bar ma gsum la dmigs te/ de dag phan tshun ltos pa'i 'du shes dang rjes su 'brel ba'i 'du shes dang mthar sdug par ro gcig tu mos par byas te sgom pa'i zhi lhag ting nge 'dzin dang shes rab mtshungs ldan dang bcas pa'o/ / gzugs med kyi rnam thar bzhi ni dgos ched rang rang gi snyoms 'jug la ro myong gi sgrib pa las grol ba'i phyir du'o/ / de la nam mkha' mtha' yas kyi skye mched kyi rnam thar ni sbyor ba'i dus na nam mkha' ltar mtha' yas so snyam du mos par byed cing*/ dngos gzhi'i dus su de nyid la gsal snang yongs su rdzogs pa'i zhi lhag ting nge 'dzin dang shes rab mtshungs ldan dang bcas pa rang gi snyoms 'jug la ro myong gi sgrib pa las grol bar byed pa'o/ / de bzhin du rnam shes mtha' yas dang ci yang med dang 'du shes med 'du shes med min gyi rnam thar rnams la'ang ci rigs par shes par bya'o/ / brgyad pa ni/ 'du shes dang tshor ba 'gog pa'i sgrib pa las grol ba'i phyir du srid rtse'i sems la brten nas tshor 'du rags pa 'gog pa'i snyoms 'jug go /

The eight forms of liberation bear the defining characteristic of causing liberation, because they bring about liberation from the obscurations to absorption (nyom juk/snyoms ‘jug). The eight are as follows. The first form of liberation is that of form-possessors viewing forms. The second is to view external forms with the outlook that internal forms do not exist. The third is the pleasant liberation, which is of the nature of the fourth concentration. The remaining five are the four formless liberations and the liberation that is the cessation of discriminations and feelings. A more extensive explanation will now be provided. As to the first form of liberation, in order to become free from the obscurations to emanation, the yogins, relying mainly on the practice of concentration, assume an outlook towards themselves as being possessors of form. They then engage in a samādhi and a supreme knowledge that enable them to imagine the forms of others to be variously pleasant and unpleasant and of greater and lesser sizes. The second is the same as the first, except for the one difference that, in it, the yogins dismantle the outlook towards themselves as possessors of form. During the third, in order to gain liberation from the obscurations of desire to emanate pleasant forms and the lack of desire to emanate unpleasant forms, the yogins, relying on the fourth concentration, dismantle the outlook of form toward themselves, and then focus on pleasant, unpleasant, and neutral forms. They engender an outlook of mutual dependence, an outlook of connectedness, and, finally, they imagine that all forms are of one taste in being of a pleasant nature. This is accompanied by the concordant factors of the shamatha and vipashyanā meditative samādhis, as well as supreme knowledge. The four formless liberations are engaged for the purpose of gaining freedom from craving toward one’s own state of absorption. First is the liberation known as limitless space.[551] At the time of approaching it, one imagines, “Space is limitless.” At the time of the main practice, one attains the full culmination of the experience of clear appearance connected to limitless space. This experience is accompanied by the concordant factors of the shamatha and vipashyanā samādhis and by supreme knowledge. Through attaining it, one gains liberations from craving one’s own absorption. This process is also applied in a correspondent way to the three other formless states: limitless consciousness, utter nonexistence, and the outlook of not existence, not nonexistence. As for the eighth form of liberation, in order to gain liberation from the obscurations to the cessation of discriminations and feelings, the yogins rely on the mental state of the peak of existence. Through this they attain the absorption that entails the cessation of coarse discriminations and feelings.
gnyis pa 'bras bu'i rang gi mtshan nyid bshad pa la/

stobs dang*/ mi 'jigs pa dang*/ so so yang dag par rig pa dang*/ byams pa chen po sogs dang*/ sangs rgyas kyi chos ma 'dres pa dang*/ rnam mkhyen gyi rang gi mtshan nyid drug gi /

The defining characteristics of the fearlessnesses 2.2.2.1.1.6.2.3.2.2.2.1.14.2.2.2.3. The defining characteristics of the correct and discerning awarenesses 2.2.2.1.1.6.2.3.2.2.2.1.14.2.2.2.4. dang po ni/
2.2.2.1.1.6.2.3.2.2.2.1.14.2.2.2.1. THE DEFINING CHARACTERISTICS OF THE POWERS
stobs rnams shin du rnam par ni/ / gtan la 'bebs pa'i rang bzhin gsungs/ /
The powers were taught to be of the nature Of decisive resolution. (6.210ab)
zhes pas bstan/ 'chad 'gyur gyi stobs bcu po rnams ni shin du rnam par ni gtan la 'bebs pa'i rang bzhin can du gsungs te/ shin du gtan la 'bebs pa nyid kyis thogs pa med pa'i phyir/
The ten powers, which will be explained,[552] were taught to be of the nature of decisive resolution (ten la bebpa/gtan la ’bebs pa). Due to this decisive resolution, they are unobstructed.
gnyis pa (mi 'jigs pa )ni/
2.2.2.1.1.6.2.3.2.2.2.1.14.2.2.2.2. THE DEFINING CHARACTERISTICS OF THE FEARLESSNESSES
skyob pa'i mi 'jigs pa rnams ni/ / shin du brtan pa'i ngo bo yin/ /
The fearlessnesses of the Protector Are of the essence of utter stability. (6.210cd)

zhes pas bstan/ skyob pa'i mi 'jigs pa rnams ni ngas chos thams cad mngon par byang chub bo zhes dam bcas pa la chos 'di byang ma chub bo zhes dge sbyong bram ze lha'am bdud dam tshangs sogs sus kyang rgol ba med pas rang don rtogs pa'i chos rnams la mi 'jigs pa dang*/ ngas zag pa thams cad zad do zhes dam bcas pa na zag pa'i rnam pa 'di ma zad do/ / zhes rgol ba po med pas rang don spangs pa'i chos la mi 'jigs pa dang*/ ngas nyan thos rnams la bar chad kyi chos su gsungs pa de dag bsten kyang bar chad du mi 'gyur ro zhes rgol ba po med pas gzhan don bar chad kyi chos bstan pa la mi 'jigs pa dang*/ ngas sdug bsngal las nges par 'byin pa'i lam du bstan pa de dag bsten kyang sdug bsngal las nges par 'byin par mi 'gyur zhes rgol ba med pas gzhan don nges par 'byin pa'i lam ston pa la mi 'jigs pa ste bzhi po 'di rnams ni shin du brtan pa'i ngo bo yin te/ sus kyang gzhan du bsgyur bar bya mi nus pa'i phyir/

The fearlessnesses of the Protector are as follows. The Buddha is fearless regarding the realization connected to benefit for self. When he proclaims, “I have gained true enlightenment regarding all phenomena,” no one, such as a bhikṣhu, Brahmin, god, māra, or Brahma could oppose that by saying, “you have not gained enlightenment with respect to this phenomena.” The Buddha is fearless regarding the relinquishment connected to benefit for self. When he proclaims, “I have exhausted all defilements,” no one can oppose that by saying, “You have not exhausted such-and-such aspect of defilement.” The Buddha is fearless in terms of teaching the phenomena of obscuration, a teaching that is connected to the benefit of others. When he teaches certain phenomena as obstacles for the hearers, no one can oppose that by saying, “Those will not become obstacles.” And the Buddha is fearless in terms of teaching the path of definite deliverance, which is connected to the benefit of others. When he teaches the path that brings definite deliverance from suffering, no one can oppose this teaching by saying, “Even through relying on those, one will not gain definitive deliverance from suffering.” These four fearlessnesses are of the essence of utter stability, because no one whosoever is capable of changing them into something else.
gsum pa (so so yang dag par rig pa )ni/
2.2.2.1.1.6.2.3.2.2.2.1.14.2.2.2.3. THE DEFINING CHARACTERISTICS OF THE CORRECT AND DISCERNING AWARENESSES
so so yang dag rig rnams ni/ / spobs sogs chad med mtshan nyid can/ /
The correct and discerning awarenesses, confidence and so on, Bear the defining characteristic of being unceasing. (6.211ab)

zhes pas bstan/ 'chad 'gyur gyi so so yang dag rig pa bzhi po rnams ni spobs pa la sogs pa don bzhi po gang la'ang chad pa'am rdugs pa med pa'i mtshan nyid can te/ yul bzhi po rnams la thags thogs med pa'i phyir/ /

Regarding the four correct and discerning awarenesses,[553] which are to be explained,[554] the four factors of the awareness of confidence and so on bear the defining characteristic of being unceasing or unobstructed, because they are free from hindrances in relation to the four objects that they engage.
bzhi pa (byams pa chen po sogs )ni/
2.2.2.1.1.6.2.3.2.2.2.1.14.2.2.2.4. THE DEFINING CHARACTERISTICS OF GREAT LOVING- KINDNESS AND SO ON[555]

'gro la phan pa nyer sgrub pa/ / byams pa chen po zhes bya'o/ /
sdug bsngal can rnams yongs skyob pa/ / thugs rje chen po'o dga' ba ni/ / rab dga'i mtshan nyid btang snyoms ni/ / ma 'dres mtshan nyid can zhes bya/ /

To thoroughly accomplish the benefit of beings Is called “great loving-kindness.” (6.211cd)
To fully protect those who are suffering Is great compassion; joy Is defined by utter joy, and impartiality Bears the defining characteristic of being unadulterated. (6.212)

zhes pas bstan/ 'gro ba sems can thams cad la gnas skabs dang mthar thug gi phan pa nye bar bsgrub pa'i mtshan nyid can ni sangs rgyas kyi byams pa chen po zhes bya'o/ / sems can sdug bsngal can rnams yongs su skyob pa ni sangs rgyas kyi thugs rje chen po'o/ / sangs rgyas kyi dga' ba chen po ni sems can kun dus thams cad par bde ba dang mi 'bral bar rab tu dga' ba'i mtshan nyid can no/ / btang snyoms chen po ni rjes chags dang khong khro sogs dang bral ba'i phyir ma 'dres pa'i mtshan nyid can du shes par bya'o/ /

That which bears the defining characteristic of thoroughly accomplishing temporary and ultimate benefit for all sentient beings is called “the great loving-kindness of the Buddha.” To fully protect those who are suffering is the great compassion of the Buddha. The great joy of the Buddha bears the defining characteristic of utter joy in all sentient beings never, at any time, being separate from happiness. Great impartiality, since it is free from attachment, anger, and so on, bears the defining characteristic of being unadulterated.
lnga pa (sangs rgyas kyi chos ma 'dres pa )ni/
2.2.2.1.1.6.2.3.2.2.2.1.14.2.2.2.5. THE DEFINING CHARACTERISTICS OF THE UNSHARED QUALITIES OF THE BUDDHA
sangs rgyas chos ni ma 'dres pa/ / bcu dang brgyad du gang 'dod dag / gang phyir ston des mi 'phrogs pa/ / de phyir mi 'phrog rang mtshan nyid/ /
The unshared qualities of the Buddha Are asserted to number eighteen. Since the Teacher cannot be deprived of them, Their defining characteristic is undeprivability. (6.213)

ces pas bstan/ sangs rgyas kyi chos ni ma 'dres pa bcu dang brgyad du gang 'dod pa dag ni bco brgyad de/ spyod pas bsdus pa drug ni/ sku la 'khrul pa mi mnga'/ gsung la ca co mi mnga'/ sems can don la bsnyel ba mi mnga'/ thugs mnyam par ma bzhag pa mi mnga'/ 'khor 'das blang dor tha dad pa'i 'du shes mi mnga'/ so sor ma brtags par gdul bya yal bar 'dor ba'i btang snyoms mi mnga' ba'o/ / rtog pas bsdus pa drug ni/ 'dun pa/ brtson 'grus/ dran pa/ ting nge 'dzin/ shes rab dang*/ rnam par grol ba rnams la nyams pa mi mnga' ba'o/ / phrin las kyis bsdus pa gsum ni/ sgo gsum gyi las thams cad ye shes mngon du 'gro zhing ye shes kyi rjes su 'brang ba'o/ / ye shes kyis bsdus pa gsum ni/ dus gsum gyi shes bya la ma chags ma thogs pa'i ye shes kyi gzigs pa 'jug pa'o/ / bco brgyad po gang yin pa de dag ni gang gi phyir ston pa sangs rgyas la 'khrul pa sogs mi mnga' bas glags med pa de nyid kyis mi 'phrogs shing thub par mi nus pa de'i phyir mi 'phrogs pa'i rang gi mtshan nyid can no/ /

The unshared qualities of the Buddha are asserted to number eighteen. There are six associated with conduct: 1) his body is free of error, 2) his speech is free of idle chatter, 3) he is not forgetful of the needs of sentient beings, 4) there is no time at which his mind is in a state of nonequipoise, 5) he is free from discriminations of viewing saṃsāra and nirvāṇa as being separate objects, with one to reject and the other to adopt, and 6) he is free from the indifference by which he would neglect beings to be tamed without having analyzed them. There are six qualities associated with realization; these are the Buddha’s being free of decline in relation to aspiration, exertion, mindfulness, samādhi, supreme knowledge, and complete liberation. There are three qualities associated with deeds; these are the Buddha’s actions in body, speech, and mind being preceded by and following after wisdom. There are three qualities associated with wisdom; these are the Buddha’s wisdom visions that see without any impediment the knowable objects of the three times. The Teacher cannot be deprived of these eighteen, for, since he is free from error, there is no chance for deprivation. Therefore these qualities of the Buddha are undeprivable and unconquerable. They bear the defining characteristic of undeprivability.[556]
drug pa (rnam mkhyen gyi rang gi mtshan nyid )ni/
2.2.2.1.1.6.2.3.2.2.2.1.14.2.2.2.6. THE DEFINING CHARACTERISTICS OF THE KNOWLEDGE OF ALL ASPECTS
rnam kun mkhyen nyid ye shes ni/ / mngon sum mtshan nyid can du 'dod/ / gzhan ni nyi tshe ba nyid kyis/ / mngon sum zhes byar mi 'dod do/ /
The wisdom of the knowledge of all aspects Is asserted to have a defining characteristic of directness. Others, which are only partial knowledges, Are not asserted to be direct. (6.214)

zhes pas bstan/ rnam pa kun mkhyen pa nyid kyi ye shes ni phung khams skye mched kyis bsdus pa'i chos thams cad kyi gnas lugs ji lta ba bzhin du mngon sum du gyur pa'i mtshan nyid can du 'dod do/ / gzhan nyan rang gi mkhyen pa ni shes bya nyi tshe ba shes pa nyid kyis rnam pa thams cad mngon sum du mkhyen pa zhes bya bar mi 'dod do/ /

The wisdom of the knowledge of all aspects is asserted to bear the defining characteristic of precisely and directly perceiving the mode of abiding of all phenomena included within the aggregates, sense-sources, and constituents. Others, i.e., the knowledges of hearers and solitary realizers, are only partial knowledges of knowable objects. Those forms of knowledge are not asserted to be direct knowledges of all aspects.
gsum pa rten bsdu zhing stong tshul gyi don bsdu ba ni/
2.2.2.1.1.6.2.3.2.2.2.1.14.3. THE SUMMARY OF THE SUPPORTS AND THE SUMMARY OF THE MODE OF EMPTINESS
gang zhig 'dus byas mtshan nyid dang*/ / 'dus ma byas pa'i mtshan nyid gang*/ / de de kho nas stong pa nyid/ / de ni rang mtshan stong pa nyid/ /

The defining characteristics of conditioned phenomena And the defining characteristics of unconditioned phenomena Are empty precisely of themselves. This is the emptiness of defining characteristics. (6.215)

ces pas bstan/ gang zhig 'dus byas kyi chos rnams kyi mtshan nyid dang 'dus ma byas pa'i chos rnams kyi mtshan nyid gang yin pa de rang rang gi ngo bo de kho na stong pa nyid de ni rang gi mtshan nyid stong pa nyid do/ /

The defining characteristics of conditioned phenomena and the defining characteristics of unconditioned phenomena are empty precisely of their own entities. This is the emptiness of defining characteristics.
bco lnga pa (mi dmigs pa )ni/
2.2.2.1.1.6.2.3.2.2.2.1.15. THE EXTENSIVE EXPLANATION OF THE EMPTINESS OF NONOBSERVATION

da ltar ba 'di mi gnas shing*/ / 'das dang ma 'ongs yod ma yin/ / gang du de dag mi dmigs pa/ / de la mi dmigs pa zhes brjod/ /
mi dmigs pa de rang ngo bo/ / de yis dben pa nyid gang de/ / ther zug gnas min 'jig min pas/ / mi dmigs zhes bya'i stong nyid do/ /

The present does not abide; The past and future do not exist. The state in which these are unobservable Is called “nonobservation.” (6.216)
Nonobservation is void Of its own entity. Since it is unchanging and does not cease, It is the emptiness of nonobservation. (6.217)

zhes pas bstan/ mi dmigs pa stong pa nyid gang zhe na/ de la ther zug tu gnas pa ma yin pa dang 'jig pa ma yin pa nyid kyi phyir mi dmigs pa ni mi dmigs pas stong ngo zhes sogs kyi don da ltar ba 'di skad cig ma yin zhing skad cig ma'ang thog mtha' dbus gsum gyis dpyad na skad cig du'ang mi gnas shing*/ 'das pa zhig pa dang*/ ma 'ongs pa ma skyes pa'i phyir yod pa ma yin pas dus gsum gang du dus gsum de dag mi dmigs pa de la mi dmigs pa zhes brjod la mi dmigs pa de rang gi ngo bo de yis dben pa nyid gang yin pa de ni ther zug gnas pa min pa dang 'jig pa min pas mi dmigs pa zhes bya ba'i stong pa nyid do/ /

What is the emptiness of nonobservation? Since it does not stay together and does not cease, nonobservation is empty of nonobservation. The meaning of the above quotation is as follows. The present is momentary. This momentariness, when analyzed in terms of its beginning, middle, and end, does not abide even for a moment. Since the past has ceased and the future has not arisen, neither the past nor the future exists. Therefore, the state of the three times in which the three times cannot be observed is called “nonobservation.” Nonobservation is devoid of its own entity, since it does not stay together and does not cease. This state is called the emptiness of nonobservation.
bcu drug pa (dngos po med pa ngo bo nyid stong pa nyid rgyas par bshad pa )ni/
2.2.2.1.1.6.2.3.2.2.2.1.16. THE EXTENSIVE EXPLANATION OF THE EMPTINESS OF THE NONEXISTENCE OF THINGS
rkyen las byung phyir dngos rnams la/ / 'dus pa pa yi ngo bo med/ / 'dus pa pa ni de nyid kyis/ / stong nyid dngos med stong nyid do/ /
Since they arise from conditions, An entity of their assembly does not exist. The emptiness of that nonexistence Is the emptiness of the nonexistence of things. (6.218)

zhes pas bstan/ de la dngos po med pa'i ngo bo nyid stong pa nyid gang zhe na/ sbyor ba las byung ba'i chos rnams kyi ngo bo nyid yod pa ma yin te/ rten cing 'brel bar 'byung ba yin pa'i phyir ro/ / ther zug tu gnas pa med pa dang*/ 'jig pa med pa'i phyir/ sbyor ba ni sbyor bas stong ngo zhes sogs kyi don rgyu dang rkyen las byung ba'i phyir dngos po rnams la 'dus pa las byung ba'i tshogs pa yis ngo bo med la 'dus pa la 'dus pa las byung ba ni de nyid kyi rang gi ngo bos stong pa nyid ni dngos po med pa'i ngo bo nyid stong pa nyid do/ / stong nyid bcu drug gi tshul la bshad rgyud rdo rje phreng ba dang*/ sam+bu Ta'i rgyud phyi ma dang dbus mtha' rtsa 'grel 'grel bshad dang bcas pa dang brgyad stong don bsdu rtsa 'grel rnams phal cher ston tshul mthun par snang na'ang nges pa'i don du 'di nas bshad pa kho na nyid gnas pa yin no/ /

What is the emptiness of the entities of nonthings? The entities of qualities that arise from conduct do not exist, because they are dependently arisen. Since it does not stay together and does not cease, juncture is empty of juncture… The meaning of the above quotation is as follows. Since they arise from causes and conditions, things have no entity of consisting in an assembly arisen from a collection of causes and conditions. The assembled and that which arises from the assembled are empty of their own entities. The emptiness of the nonexistence of such entity is the emptiness of the nonexistence of things. There are many lineages of explanation of the sixteen emptinesses, such as the Vajra Garland (Vajravalī, Dorje Trengwa/rdo rje phreng ba), the later Sambuta tantras, the root text, commentaries, and explanations of [Maitreya’s] Distinguishing the Middle from the Extremes, and the root text and commentary to [Dignāga’s] Summary of the Eight Thousand Lines (Gye Tong Dön Du/brgyad stong don bsdu). The methods of teaching of all of these are for the most part in harmony with each other. However, to obtain an explanation of the definitive meaning, one must keep strictly to what is explained here in this context of the Middle Way teaching tradition.

2.2.2.1.1.6.2.3.2.2.2.2.1. THE EMPTINESS OF THINGS
dngos po'i sgras ni mdor bsdus na/ / phung po lnga rnams brjod pa yin/ / de rnams de yis stong nyid gang*/ / de dngos stong pa nyid du bshad/ /
The term “thing” refers, in brief, To the five aggregates. The emptiness of those five aggregates of themselves Is explained to be the emptiness of things. (6.219)

What is the emptiness of things? The term “thing” refers to the appropriated aggregates. To summarize the meaning of the above sixteen emptinesses, the Entrance to the Middle Way will now describe the four emptinesses. The term “thing” refers, in brief, to the five aggregates. The emptiness of those aggregates of themselves is the emptiness of things.
gnyis pa (dngos po med pa )ni/
2.2.2.1.1.6.2.3.2.2.2.2.2. THE EMPTINESS OF NONTHINGS
mdor bsdus na ni dngos med pa/ / 'dus ma byas chos rnams la brjod/ / de nyid dngos med des stong nyid/ / dngos po med pa stong nyid do/ /
In brief, “nonthing” Refers to unconditioned phenomena. Nonthings’ being empty of themselves Is the emptiness of nonthings. (6.220)

zhes pas bstan/ dngos po med pa stong pa nyid gang zhe na/ dngos po med pa zhes bya ba ni 'dus ma byas la brjod do zhes sogs kyi don mdor bsdu na ni/ dngos po med par brjod pa'am grags pa ni nam mkha' dang mya ngan las 'das pa sogs 'dus ma byas kyi chos rnams la brjod la/ dngos med de nyid dngos med de nyid kyis stong pa nyid ni dngos po med pa stong pa nyid ces brjod do/ /

What is the emptiness of nonthings? “Nonthing” refers to unconditioned phenomena. To summarize the meaning of the above quotation, the expression “nonthing” refers to unconditioned phenomena such as space and nirvāṇa. The emptiness of nonthings of themselves is called “the emptiness of nonthings.”
gsum pa (rang gi ngo bo )ni/
2.2.2.1.1.6.2.3.2.2.2.2.3. THE EMPTINESS OF PHENOMENA’S OWN ENTITIES
rang bzhin ngo bo nyid med ni/ / rang bzhin zhes bya'i stong nyid de/ / 'di ltar rang bzhin ma byas pas/ / rang bzhin zhes ni bya bar bsnyad/ /
The absence of an essential nature Is the emptiness of nature. Since it was not created by anyone, It is called “nature.” (6.221)

ces pas bstan/ de la rang gi ngo bo stong pa nyid gang zhe na rang gi ngo bo ni shes pa dang mthong bas ma byas pa'i phyir na phyin ci ma log pa'i rang bzhin no zhes sogs kyi don chos rnams kyi rang bzhin chos thams cad rang gi ngo bo nyid med pa ni rang bzhin zhes bya ba'i stong pa nyid de 'di ltar chos rnams kyi rang bzhin nyan thos la sogs pa'i shes mthong gis ma byas pas na rang bzhin zhes ni bya bar bsnyad do/ /

What is the emptiness of own-essence? Own-essence is not created through being known or seen. Therefore it is the unerring nature. The meaning of the above is as follows. The nature of phenomena—the nonexistence of any phenomenon’s own entity—is the emptiness of nature. Since it was not created by the hearers and so on by their knowing or seeing the nature of phenomena, it is called “nature.”

2.2.2.1.1.6.2.3.2.2.2.2.4. THE EMPTINESS OF OTHER ENTITIES

sangs rgyas rnams ni byung ba'am/ / ma byung yang rung dngos su na/ / dngos po kun gyi stong pa nyid/ / gzhan gyi dngos por rab tu bsgrags/ /
yang dag mtha' dang de bzhin nyid/ / de gzhan dngos po'i stong nyid do/ /

Whether buddhas arise Or not, in reality The emptiness of all things remains. Therefore it is excellently proclaimed to be an “other entity.” (6.222)
This emptiness, which is also called “the perfect limit” and “suchness,” Is the emptiness of other entities. (6.223ab)

zhes pas bstan/ gzhan gyi ngo bo stong pa nyid gang zhe na/ de bzhin gshegs pa rnams byung yang rung ma byung yang rung ste chos rnams kyi chos nyid gnas pa nyid dang chos kyi dbyings nyid dang chos nges pa nyid dang de bzhin nyid dang gzhan ma yin pa de bzhin nyid dang yang dag pa'i mtha' gang yin pa 'di ni gnas pa nyid de gzhan gyis ma byas so zhes sogs kyi don sangs rgyas rnams ni 'byung ba'am ma byung yang rung ste dngos su na dngos po kun gyi gnas lugs dang de kho na nyid ni stong pa nyid yin zhing don tha snyad du ci'i ngo bor yang ma grub par rtag tu yod pas ye shes phul du byung bas rtogs bya yin pa'i phyir gzhan gyi dngos por rab tu bsgrags so/ / yang na 'khor ba las 'das pa'i phyir pha rol na yod pa ni gzhan gyi dngos po ste yang dag pa'i mtha' dang rnam par 'gyur ba med pas de bzhin nyid stong pa nyid kyi mtshan nyid can de ni gzhan gyi dngos po'i stong pa nyid do/ / de dag gis bsdus tshul dang pos 'dus byas kyis bsdus pa'i stong nyid thams cad dang*/ gnyis pas don dam dang 'dus ma byas kyis bsdus pa'i stong nyid thams cad dang*/ gsum pas rang bzhin stong pa nyid rnams dang*/ bzhi pas stong pa nyid stong pa nyid bsdus shing de bzhin nyid dang yang dag mtha' sogs rang gi ngo bos mi stong ba'i gzhan stong du 'dod pa'i log rtog bsal ba'i phyir smos so/ / des na bzhir bcu drug kyang 'dus so/ / dgag sgrub mtha' dpyad gnyis TI kar 'byung ngo*/ /

The sūtras say: What is the emptiness of other entities? Whether the tathāgatas arise or do not arise, the dharmatā of phenomena abides. The dharmadhātu, the definitive dharma, suchness, the suchness that is not other, and the perfect limit—all of these abide, because they are not created by others. The meaning of the above is as follows. Whether buddhas arise or not, in reality the abiding mode and the suchness of all things is emptiness. Conventionally, it always exists while not being established as any kind of entity. Therefore, since it is an object of realization of sublime wisdom, it is excellently proclaimed to be an “other entity.” Alternatively, it is called “the perfect limit”: since it is beyond saṃsāra, and exists on the “other side” of saṃsāra, it is an “other entity.” Since it does not change in its manifestation, it is “suchness.” These descriptors, which bear the defining characteristic of emptiness, refer to the emptiness of different things. The following is a description of how the four emptinesses encompass the sixteen emptinesses. The first of the four emptinesses includes all emptiness that involve conditioned phenomena. The second emptiness includes all emptinesses that involve ultimate, unconditioned phenomena. The third emptiness includes the emptinesses of nature, and the fourth includes the emptiness of emptiness. The fourth emptiness was taught in order to dispel the misconception of asserting suchness, the perfect limit, and so on to be an extrinsic emptiness that is not empty of its own entity. Therefore, it should be understood that the sixteen emptinesses are included in these latter four. The Ṭīkā here presents extensive refutations, positions, and critical analyses.
gsum pa don bsdu ba ni/
shes rab pha rol phyin tshul las/ / de dag de skad rab tu bsgrags/ /
These emptinesses were excellently proclaimed In the teachings of the perfection of supreme knowledge. (6.223cd)

These emptinesses which were just explained, the elaborate categorization of sixteen and the brief categorization of four, were excellently proclaimed in the sūtras falling under the category of the mother of all victorious ones—the perfection of supreme knowledge.
